content:
r 17, 2014
												I first played the original PC version of FF7, and then later the PlayStation version.After purchasing and replaying the Steam version, I can wholly recommend it as the definitive version of Final Fantasy VII to play. I'll start off with some quick points about this version in comparison to previous versions. The actual game will be discussed in more detail below.Vs Playstation:+Smoother look on the characters+No disc swapping+English translation has been tidied up and the plot is more coherent (No one seems to talk about this, but it's major in my eyes)-Swearwords have been replaced with !@#$ style characters.Vs original PC release:+Hassle-free, in my experience (40+ hours) <-- This is the key thing for me.+PSX music added, as opposed to the awful original PC music. Huge plus! The song "One Winged Angel" now has vocals like it should do :)+Rendered characters are now synced perfectly when walking over a pre-rendered video.+Videos look smoother and match the PSX version, which is very nice in comparison to original release.-Default keyboard controls need two hands. Original PC release had default keys all on the Numpad. Meaning you can scratch your chin or drink coffee while playing. Easily resolved anyway :)-Yet another thing you have to create an account for. This time for Square Enix. Once you've done so, you can pretty much forget about it.I have an Xbox controller, but never tried it admittedly, so can't comment on that! I found the game plays perfectly with keyboard.It's surprising how well Final Fantasy VII has aged. I hadn't played the game for nearly 7 years now, and was expecting it to be incredibly ugly. Don't get me wrong, it IS incredibly ugly, albeit in a charming way now. Rather than a good looking game being badly ported, this is a bad looking game that's been ported just right. You can't change your resolution (to my knowledge), but there's absolutely no need to. The game makes use of pre-rendered backgrounds and the resolution they chose for the 3D characters was a good compromise between smoothness and not sticking out too much from the backgrounds. It does look much better than the PSX version, and a bit better than the original PC release.I am also happy that they stuck with the original PC version's English translation. If you've only ever played FF7 on one platform before, you may not know that the PC version had a much neater, tidier translation. I'm not talking about a complete overhaul like some of the other Final Fantasy remakes. This is still the original story told in what the original PSX translation was trying to do. Any line that was fine before, is unchanged. They simply removed some (admittedly funny) spelling mistakes, and only changed lines that really did not make any sense at all. It makes the game feel more natural and therefore I highly recommend a replay if you've only played on the PSX before. The one noticeable, and unfortunate, change is that the swearing has been replaced with !@#£ style symbols. You can still tell they're swearing and what word they were going to say, but this unnecessary censorship felt a bit out of place. Still, it doesn't make or break the game. And just to be clear, this isn't new to the Steam version as it was present on the original PC release.Also, as I might as well say it now: The story IS really good. As FF7 is one of the most popular entries in the franchise, it sometimes gets a lot of flak from people who seem to only want to dislike popular things. These are personal games, which you should play for yourself, and FF7 offers a deceptively complex story, with a fantastic combination of twists. 'Twist' is a harsh word, because it implies a sudden and unexpected change in the story's direction. This is not the case. The 'twists' are completely natural and only serve to make everything before fit into place better. The combination I mentioned earlier is in reference to twists which you will definitely understand on your first time through, and some which may only make sense with a bit of thinking or a replay. The latter are not essential to understand, but you'll feel a satisfying sense of revelation if you do. All in all, this is a well-thought out constructed tale. It may not be as fast-paced as you'd like, but the end result is very satisfactory.The gameplay itself is surprisingly fast for a 90s JRPG. You can get through battles pretty quickly, and most of the attack animations are short enough to not be too annoying. With the exception of summons; huge magical attacks shown in a lengthy animation of a monster being summoned and inflicting damage on your enemies.The Materia system is still great and offers lots of customisation for your characters, although it's not as complex nowadays as it used to be. To be clear, Materia are 'gems' which you attach to characters to give them extra abilities or magic. As a Materia is used, it gains its own experience and gets progressively more powerful. The only complexity comes from managing who has what materia, and this is the one area of the game where the age really shows. You can only quick swap between character's Materia screens for the three characters in your party, rather than every available character. Therefore you are forced to constantly swap characters in and out to get the best setup. [EDIT: A number of comments have corrected me and pointed me to the Exchange option, which negates this complaint of mine!]Is it worth £10? Admittedly, this port probably generated no where near the amount of work needed to justify the price, but the quality of the game does. Therefore it's a tough question to answer. I suppose if you look at what you're getting, then yes, it is worth the price. Your first time through the game can literally take 60-70 hours. My replay was 40 hours long, and I know the game extremely well.This is now my favorite way to play Final Fantasy VII. And that is probably the one thing you needed to know.EDIT: Voted this game for "Villain most in need of a hug" award ;)

content:
, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII is a classic, there's no debating that. With it's first release on the Playstation back in 1997, this release is a repackaged version of the PC port released in 1998.  With cloud saves and achievements, it doesn't really stand out to people who may have already bought the game or have it elsewhere.Final Fantasy VII uses almost all the assets from the original PC version of the game. Music was re-encoded to OGG Vorbis, but was still based off of fairly ugly MIDI tracks that the PC used. Thankfully they are easy to replace as some poeple have even decided to use remixes of said tracks instead.Visually the game is very dated. 2D backgrounds, 3D sprites from that era with resolution stretching 2D elements while providing a modicum amount of improvement to the 3D models. While in the field, higher resolutions don't really help, but in battle scenes and in full 3D environments (Chocobo Racing, Submarine Minigame), there is a noticeable improvement.Controls are a bit awkward as for a 360 controller, the triggers, d-pad, and right stick aren't usable. However, you can get around that either by binding everything to usable controls or using a utility like JoytoKey.This is a bare-bones re-release, with the hard work for making it work with a modern OS stripped away for most people.Update: SquareEnix has managed to replace the MIDI quality music with PSX quality tracks. This means the game's music sounds extremely detailed compared to the original PC release.

content:
y 11, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Final Fantasy 7 Original Release: 1998 (2013 Steam Version) Genre Tags: JRPG; Turn-Based RPG; Action; Classic; Industry Jewel My Overall Grade: A+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 20-65 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Nostalgia chasers; Strong narrative advocates; Gaming industry aficionado REVIEWIf you scroll down the (serious) positive reviews for this game, you no doubt see many people expressing their nostalgic love for this legendary piece of their childhood. I stand among these people. For many of us who were kids in the 90s, Final Fantasy 7 was and always will be the first truly epic game we ever played. So I’ll admit that I am definitely biased to love it, as it was my personal favorite game during a number of years of my childhood. But that isn’t why I’m going to recommend that you consider trying it. You should consider it because Final Fantasy 7 is a classic piece of video-game history that revolutionized the genre and because it’s a kickass game. At the time it first released, there were a handful of other large RPGs with huge worlds and a lot of gameplay (relative to the era), but they were uncommon and unpopular in the Western world. Final Fantasy 7 reached a pinnacle of awesomeness for RPGs that was unprecedented and subsequently elevated the genre into the mainstream gaming market outside of Japan. Not only did it have sound RPG fundamentals, but the sheer amount of variety of gameplay it offered was quite revolutionary for the genre. Chocobo racing and breeding, the motorbike scene, the snowboard scene, the Golden Saucer, the Don Corneo segment, and more all contributed to shattering the status quo for the genre. A lot of young gamers went from not knowing about RPGs to one of them being their favorite game ever. Not only that, but it became one of the cornerstones which provided a foundation for the genre to grow towards what it has become today. If there was a Video Game Hall of Fame, Final Fantasy 7 would no doubt be in it. Obviously, with more recent RPG blockbusters from franchises like The Elder Scrolls, The Witcher, and Fallout, it is hard to continue to consider Final Fantasy 7 to be an “epic” game by today’s standards. Somehow it still feels that way to me. Or at the very least: since I enjoy the genre, I still find it quite fun to play.So I will admit that it definitely has been a long time since Final Fantasy 7 was one of the best games in existence. That said, even after the erosion of the sands of time, the game still feels exciting, intriguing, and massive to me. Even on my 8th playthrough I pick up on new subtleties in the story or discover new secrets and items. The story is interesting, if not a bit convoluted. (Some of the story was cut away to make it “less confusing for the Western market” or some such silliness. This wound up making it more confusing.) The Materia system is fun and, combined with the traditional XP leveling, continuously offers the satisfaction of progress as you play through the campaign. The world is intriguing and still semi-large(ish) even by modern standards. The characters are perfect clichés of the very clichés that they themselves introduced. And one of the best parts of the game will always be the intimidating boss battles with the signature music. It is doubtful there will ever be another kid who says Final Fantasy 7 is his favorite game ever, but most modern fans of the genre will enjoy this game despite its age.So there are a few reasons you may want to consider trying this game if you never have.If you consider yourself a true aficionado of the gaming industry, you will probably want to play Final Fantasy 7 at least once in your life. Even though there is a “remake” on the way (or out by the time you read this), I would argue you should play this version at least once to really experience a legendary piece of video game history in this semi-unadulterated state.Or: if you don’t care about any of the historical mumbo-jumbo, and just are looking for a fun, turn-based JRPG, then you can comfortably look to Final Fantasy 7 for that as well.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
y 6, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Analog Recommends: Final Fantasy VII 

			Views: 2,317		

			Trent looks back at the JRPG classic that came to define a generation of gaming... Please like and subscribe for more reviews, gameplay, and discussions!		

Based on it's simple ultra low poly chibi characters and it's low resolution, pre-rendered backdrops, younger gamers would have a hard time believing that Final Fantasy VII was a cutting edge title in 1997. In addition to being a technical marvel in it's day, along side Resident Evil, Metal Gear Solid, Super Mario 64 and Ocarina of Time, it was an important ambassador for the potential of 3d graphics in gaming. Squaresoft had been working for some time to make their characters more emotive in order to sell their grand fantasy stories. With it's pre rendered cut scenes and fresh diesel punk and cyber punk informed sci-fi setting it allowed JRPGs to explode in popularity in the west. Boasting one of the most thrilling openings in RPG history, players take control of Cloud Strife as he joins the terrorist group AVALANCH in order to destroy a Mako reactor. Cloud's former employer, an evil corporation named Shinra, is using these reactors to harvest a new form of energy that is destroying the planet and each of AVALANCH's members has a personal reason to fight against Shinra except for Cloud. Annoyingly enough, Cloud starts off as an angsty, aloof ♥♥♥♥♥♥ but slowly opens up, dealing with his own bag of issues over the course of the game. The rest of the cast is colorful and generally likeable. During the fight against Shinra a new threat emerges, shaking the plot up and introducing players to one of the most iconic villains in history. It's a narrative that is compelling though it seems a bit more silly now than it did upon release. Square has desperately tried to recapture the magic of Final Fantasy VII and often it feels like they have only managed to parody their own classic game. Final Fantasy VII established several character archetypes that are regularly found in many modern Final Fantasy titles and they have never been as likable as they were in VII.  What hasn't been cheapened by the failures of subsequent Final Fantasy titles is the combat mechanics. While the turn based structure may feel slow by modern standards, the materia system remains a phenomenally flexible system that effects everything from what weapons you want to use to your character's stats. Materia are magic crystals that are a byproduct of the mako reactors in the game world and allow characters to use magic. Each materia falls into one of several catagories: spell, command, support and summon materia. Each weapon and piece of armor has a number of slots to place materia in and some slots are linked allowing support skills to compliment offensive materia. For instance a poison materia linked to an added effect materia on a weapon allows characters to poison enemies or deal elemental damage. Final attack materia combined with life materia will instantly revive characters when they fall in combat giving yo a second chance during tough encounters. Characters don't really have classes, statistically some are better suited for certain roles than others but the right equipment allows any character to function in a desired role.  Personally, what has burned Final Fantasy VII into the deepest part of my memory for the past 17 years has been the soundtrack. From it's delicate melodies to it's whimsical themes, the soundtrack to this RPG classic is every bit as ambitious and epic as the rest of it's design. Since characters relay their dialog in text, the soundtrack serves as their voice. Hearing a character's theme several years after playing the game is like hearing the voice of an old friend. There is more humor, love, suspense and wonder in this game's sound scape than many entire franchises. Final Fantasy VII is a classic and it's certainy worth revisiting for even experiencing for the first time. Thanks to a recent re-release on steam as well as versions available on the PlayStation network that's pretty easy to do. Unfortunately the port for steam isn't exactly exemplary. The controller support requires a mod to function properly, there are a handful of bugs and it requires registering with Square Enix. On the upside, there is cloud save support and achievements. In any case, I'd buy a lackluster port of a bonna fide classic if it convinces Square Enix to take a break from releasing embarrassing new entries into their flagship franchise in order to give gamers new and old a properly remade version of what is, arguably, the most popular game in their company's history.

It may also be processed by personnel operating outside the EEA who work for us or for one of our suppliers."^Wow...a big 1990's style internet back door into my computer.(theres more but it all wont fit!, go have a read to find more, because there's plenty more)All this for a 15 year old single player game from the 90's...28th March 2017: It has been years, and i still have not gotten my money back. content:
0, 2015
												Final Fantasy VII was one of the first RPGs I played, and the first game I bought for the Playstation. I had never seen anything like it at the time. Such a big, immersive experience. Three discs long! It was the first time I had seen a game span multiple discs. There's a lot to cover, so let's get started.Breakdown of the game itself:Graphics - The graphics in FF7 are very much a mixed bag. The 3D models used in battle are about as detailed as you could achieve for 1997, at least for console gaming. The models used outside of battle, however, are very blocky and much smaller. They sort of look like squashed down versions. It may take some getting used to if you're coming from a game like FF8, for example. FF7 uses pre-rendered backgrounds, which looked far superior to the 3D textures of the time and look great on standard def TVs, but look a little pixellated on higher res computer monitors. The FMVs still hold up pretty well, even if they're nothing mind blowing like they were for some of us back in the day. Personally, I think the spell/attack animations hold up the best out of everything, graphics-wise. I love seeing the animation for spells such as Aqualung. :)Music - FF7 has some of the best music ever put into a video game, if you ask me. Nobuo Uematsu is a fantastic composer, and this game simply wouldn't be anywhere near as charming and compelling without his score, which does an incredible job of setting the mood for much of the game. Many of the tracks will tug at your heartstrings during the game's more emotional scenes, and many other tracks... Well, they just sound plain cool. The boss battle theme really got me pumped the first time I heard it, and I used to look forward to upcoming boss fights just so I could hear that music again.Battle mechanics - FF7 uses an active time turn based battle system. You can have three characters in your active party, and each can equip a weapon, armor and accessory. Each weapon and armor has slots in it, which you can place little orbs in called materia. Materia are where you get your special abilities. Without them, you only have the standard attack and item commands during battle. Materia come in five varieties: Green, which contain magic spells. Blue, which alter the effects of a materia it is placed next to, if those two slots are linked. Red, which contain summons. Yellow, which enable extra battle commands (Steal, for example). And purple, which are basically stat boosting materia. These categories of materia are referred to as magic (green), support (blue), summon (red), command (yellow) and independent (purple). There is a TON of materia in the game and each weapon and armor can hold up to 8 materia orbs, so character customization possibilities are practically limitless. The materia system is honestly one of my favourites of any Final Fantasy or RPG.Plot - You are Cloud, a former soldier of the Shinra corporation, which is basically the biggest world power in Final Fantasy VII. After parting ways with them, Cloud embarks on a new life as a mercenary, ironically being hired by a militant anti-Shinra group known as Avalanche. As you progress through the game you'll learn more about Cloud and his comrades' pasts and the various secrets the Shinra corporation holds, as well as the mako energy that's become so profitable for them. Along the way you'll meet lots of interesting characters, and there are even two optional ones you can recruit. I think that's a pretty good outline without venturing into spoilery territory. The characters in this game really have a lot of depth, for the most part, which is one of my favourite aspects of the game.Controls - FF7 was originally released for the Playstation, but didn't make use of the analog sticks. It used the D-pad to move your character around, so you should be able to configure it to work with just about any USB gamepad you happen to have. You can also use your keyboard if you don't have a gamepad or simply prefer not to use one.Issues specific to the Steam release:First off, if you get an error when launching the game, try going into your program files (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\FINAL FANTASY VII\ for example) and right-click on FF7_Launcher.exe. Select "Properties" and go into the Compatibility tab. Here, tick the box that says "Run this program as an administrator." This fixed the issue for me on my Windows 7 machine.The only other issues I've had running the game have been it crashing a few times. Once when I first played through it on my laptop in 2013, just outside of the Mythril Mines (after travelling through them), and a couple times when casting Beta on my current playthrough. Not ideal, but nothing to really worry about. Just make sure you save often and always after a major accomplishment.So, a few things about the Steam port. For one thing, you now have achievement trophies. These are little badges that show up on your Steam profile to let all your friends know how awesome you are, lol. Well, something like that. You'll gain a badge for getting to certain points in the story, and there are badges for getting the most powerful limit breaks, maxing out your characters' levels, collecting materia, beating optional bosses, etc.One big change I'd like to talk about is the sound. The music in the Steam release is nowhere near the quality of the original Playstation version's. Luckily, this can easily be remedied by searching through Steam's mod section, where you can find mods to replace it with the original music, or even higher quality mixes (I recommend the one based around FinalFanTim's remastered soundtrack). :)There are a few other little changes here and there. Some of the dialog has been cleaned up a little, a few of the curses have been replaced with the iconic @%#$% characters, and... The models have mouths. Basically little black circles pasted onto their faces. It looks pretty silly to me, but it's not a major distraction (you can also mod the graphics if you're so inclined).I think that about covers it... Final Fantasy VII is widely regarded as one of the best JRPGs of all time, and it's definitely high on my personal list. Give it a try. For $11.99, it's well worth it.

er 30, 2013
												Bought this for the Nostalga trip I was looking forward to. and I would love to recommend the game, except for a few quite significant things:* Online activation of the Single-Player, Offline game before it will work. This relies on SE's servers working, which they didn't at the time of this review.* You MUST have or create a Square account before it will launch. This is *Mandatory*, so yet another set of credentials that will need to be created and remembered. Haven't gone through that process yet because of outages. - No clear warning on the STEAM page for this game.* From a brand new install, the ff7_en.exe file gets picked up by AV applications like Comodo apparently as malware, even though it's clean. This is apparently a known issue, and has been since July 2013 at least - There is NO warning about this on the STEAM purchase page.How the hell can you butcher something so badly? I haven't even managed to launch the thing successfully yet due to these issues, which is why I have a stunning 0.2 hrs on record for the game, attempting to launch, get to the auth part, then then AV eating the .exe .. I shouldn't have to make an exception in AV settings for a game.This is a SINGLE PLAYER GAME, and I was mistaken in thinking the Cloud saves and such were STEAM based - They are NOT. Maybe I'll come back to it and try again another time. Right now, it's uninstall and added to the "I regret this purchase" pile. My mistake for not researching deep enough before buying.Thanks for butchering the memories Square.Edit - They have finally put in that it requires a Square Enix Account in italics at the very bottom of the system requirements.

content:
ber 20, 2016
												From a new player who never had a Playstation growing up:What more really needs to be said? It's that game that has the legacy that no other RPG has ever attained. I went back to this because I never had a Playstation when I was a kid, and practically any time I've had a discussion about games of the past this one always came up, so when it came to Steam I had to give it a try. At first, it just sat in my library for nearly a year before I picked it up, because there was plenty of other stuff for me to play. But one day when I had the time and was like "eh, why not?" I finally did.After several days of playing from day until night, I understood why this game is important. I understand why FFVII is etched into history as the most famous RPG of all time. And I only just played and beat it for the first time like 2 years ago.If you're curious, I promise it's worth it. And the people who say it doesn't hold up may have a point, because RPGs have evolved vastly over the years, which might make this feel less special if you've played others before you give this one a try. But it does not take away from the fact that it is still an excellent game. Hell, here I am writing up a Steam review (regardless of how unneccessary it is) because I revisited the game again today, and seeing the empty review textbox felt like an invitation for me to pour my heart out for a game that, while new to me, I feel the same kind of love for as games I have been playing for the past 2 decades.I mean, you decide. I just spent like 20 minutes gushing about it to complete strangers that aren't even going to respond to me because FFVII clearly doesn't even need my positive review, because it's just going to get buried under all of the other positive reviews.

content:
29, 2016
												I could go on and on about FF7. But I think it's the Nostalgia talking. I grew up with this. I was a hardcore Nintendo fanboy, loved my N64, until one day I walked into a Blockbuster (Oh yeah, I'm that old) and in the store they had a playable demo of FF7 (Yeah seriously that old). I was instantly absorbed. I'm sure younger people won't get why so many older people go on about FF7, it isn't a matter of it being timeless exactly, though I still love the story. I think it's a matter of if you grew up playing video games in the 90's, this was just something else. There really had never been something quite like FF7. It wasn't a kids game, it was an over the top action title, it was serious and dark (relative to the era again). It had/has amazing music, a deep story and narrative, one of the most classic villains in gaming, one of the first and most powerful death scenes in gaming and had a great battle system. Again though, this was all for its time (Except for the soundtrack, it's still wonderful). By todays standards I'm not sure it compares so well, especially since RPG's have really changed in a lot of core ways, from combat to dialogue, it just doesn't work the way RPGs today do. It requires time, a lot of it, investment and interest. If you're the kind of gamer who just clicks through unspoken dialogue you should probably pass, if you play games in a hurry and don't walk around searching areas and talking to random NPCs, you should probably pass yet again. You get into FF7 to get into a story the way book worms get into a book, this is an investment on your end. You should celebrate the characters triumpths and mourn their losses. I'm sure that sounds silly to many, but that was the era of gaming this was a part of. We weren't CoD junkies who lived for point and click gratification, we wanted stories, and not the stories that our parents had, these were OUR stories, these were the new stories of our childhoods, we just didn't know it yet.

number of helpful: 164 of 208 people (79%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
r 27, 2014
												Back in 2005,I was handed a pirated game by my friend."You HAVE to play this!". Curious,I installed and played the game on my then-fossil PC and found myself lost into the game for weeks!For I discovered a new genre.RPG,as the cool kids used to say.Cut forward to 9 years.RPG Scenario has completely changed with Bethesda and Bioware as the demigods of WRPG.Souls' franchise has been hailed as the masochist's paradise.CD Projekt Red is promising to deliver possibly the most epic game in terms of both scope and and scale.Square's Final Fantasy is struggling to keep up with its contemporaries due to the recent games which have been a complete blunder and is on the very verge of downfall should the next game fail.So how does a primitive game like Final Fantasy VII hold up today?{TL;DR Version Down Below}PRESENTATION:Oh, Final Fantasy VII was a complete looker for a game to be released in 1997 and the first game in series to have 3D graphics.Polygon textures, Pre-rendered cutscenes, Modelled character designs were the terms people heard for the first time.Storyline is above average but its narrative and storytelling is ace! This game proved that Square Soft knew how to do story right.They do have a few plotholes, but they aren't enough to bring the whole experience down.  Sure the game itself looks supremely fossil for today's standards.But when a game has memorable characters with zero voice acting...yes,picture this.. Characters with no voice actors that were memorable!So yes, Great characters, a plot that just oozes intrigue to be uncovered and soul-rending music, Final Fantasy VII represents all that which the recent games seem to be lacking.GAMEPLAY:Final Fantasy VII is am old school JRPG in every sense which boasts an open-world setting, turn-based combat and some annoying mini-games.But you'll be interested in the former two aspects. The character progression system requires you to be playing a lot of hours because once you hit Level20,you are going to need a LOT of XP points to progress.For that reason I found myself farming XP for hours,that can be frustrating for some. The game does get tough eventually so you'll need to keep your character's levels higher and equip them with better gear from time to time.Turn-based combat is also very well implemented with "Materia System" which is incredibly deep and allows for some interesting mix-and-match combinations.The influence of its combat can be seen in recent games like South Park:The Stick of Truth and Child of Light. It takes a while for the game to open up.By end of first 7 hours, you almost learn everything you should about the mechanics and systems.Animations are still clunky and stick-like, meaning its still the unchanged PS1 version you're playing.While it does have Keyboard support, you'll still want to play using a gamepad.The game can be completed within 40hours.Even more if you try to unlock all characters, learn all techniques and defeat the additional bosses. For most part, the game fulfills your needs for everything Role-playing.{FOR TL;DR SPAMMERS}PROS:+Satisfying storyline and narrative+Great characters+Robust combat+Reasonably challenging+Sublime music and OST+Features one of the best antagonists in video game culture CONS:-Graphics sure look outdated.VERDICT:An absolute piece of masterwork.Final Fantasy VII was an achievement in RPG genre when it released.The later games in the series sure had upgraded visuals and graphics but none of them come close to this one when it came to capturing the very soul of what makes RPG an RPG, like VII did.All said and considered,Final Fantasy VII is the best game in FF series and one of the best JRPG of all time.If you are a self-proclaimed fanatic of this genre,then pick this one up whenever you can. You owe it to yourself.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Final Fantasy is back. Again. For the 3rd time. But what's nice is this game is fully optimized to play on new hardware. I won't go into specifics on what Final Fantasy VII is all about, since unless you have been living under a rock, you already know. But for those rock dwellers, I will give some basics. Final Fantasy VII is an epic turn based RPG. One of the finest in its genre. It has a grand story. Memorable characters. An amazing soundtrack. Everything has aged wonderfully, except I'd say the visuals. Luckily with the power of the MOD, you can relive this classic with a fresh spin of the visuals (just search around) giving you a new experience on this gem. The only problem with modding FFVII is that you will need to roll back the exe which will in turn disable any achievements. So I'd suggest for achievement hunters that you play through the game unmodded. And replay it later with the beautiful mods added. With that said, aside from better new system support, this re-release of FFVII also adds a higher res for the included character designs, as well as cloud saving, and a mode which will increase HP and Gil, with a seemingly tedious process. The latter mode is completely optional, but works in a way which does not hamper any enemy level scaling. It only boosts HP/MP, and not any stats or levels. So you will get the same scaling flow you would when playing it normally. This however does mess with your limit meter. So use at your own risk. either way, FFVII is a great classic. Fans of it originally should check out this re-release. And newcomers need to experience this at least once in their lives.

number of helpful: 92 of 111 people (83%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
21, 2015
												Honestly, I don't care much for writing these glowing pieces on highly-acclaimed games. It's the whole "preaching to the choir" aspect that bothers me. I ran into this before back when I reviewed Resident Evil 4. Everyone knows FF7 is a great game, so why even bother with the review? I should just save myself the time & effort, make a humorous reference, then sit my ♥♥♥ down and drink...oh right. So I have to say something significant. I have to put words on a page that somehow match the importance and majesty of this classic JRPG. So let's get started.Like any other game series, Final Fantasy has had its humble beginnings, its ups, downs, controversies, and even today we're uncertain of where it'll go next. Like any good lemming we follow along, buy the latest games, all the while hoping that eventually Square-enix will take the franchise back in the direction we want it to go in. The thing is, there's always been one path, and game-development isn't about what "we" want. FF13 might be a wildly different game compared to FF1, but if you played through most of them, you could see how such a divisive entry could be released. It's the accumulation of elements, taking what works, changing what doesn't, and evolving into something different. But we're getting a little ahead of ourselves.Final Fantasy 7 is probably not the best JRPG of all time. When it comes to opinions; I don't touch best/worst anything. FF7 is a great JRPG, and certainly a remarkable entry in the series. Part of its quality is in its spectacle. Yes, I'm actually talking about the flashy stuff. Even in its earliest entries, Final Fantasy was always about grandness. In FF3 for the Famicom there was the discovery that your world, was just a tiny floating island in a much larger world. FF7 works in a similar fashion, with that tiny island being Midgar. The battles in FF games have always pushed for more special effects. Everyone remembers their first time casting Ultima in FF6, just like the first time they summoned Knights of the Round. This touches on another aspect of FF. No effort (no matter how slight) goes unrewarded. One of the aspects I've always enjoyed about FF, is that I can wander into a forest in the middle of nowhere, and possibly bump into a unique monster. Perhaps this monster has a cool special move, that looks really neat, and maybe I'll be able to make it my own (via blue magic or otherwise). Other entries (like FF9) mix things up, like having mini quiz-shows hiding in the forest. It relates to one of my favorite aspects of the original Baldur's Gate. By simply wandering the outskirts you're bound to encounter more than just monsters. There's a lot of neat little discoveries in the dozen or so optional areas BG1 had. FF7 is a much more linear game, yet it still understands the importance of deviation.The character models...I actually can't complain about them. Yes, nowadays we can simply mod everything so that it looks uniformly superb but...well I'm starting to see the appeal of those blocky wonders. This isn't nostalgia talking either, this is something I just noticed in my most recent play-through. Squaresoft put a lot of work into giving NPCs life. Even today, NPCs in RPGs are only good at standing around, walking in random directions, or (in the case of later Bethesda RPGs) doing a bunch of "radiant dynamic AI" actions that somehow look more robotic than if they were just scripted. A lot of NPCs in FF7 do things, memorable things, things that humans would actually do. Early in the game, there's this woman waiting at a train-station. Now this woman isn't anyone important. In fact, you're supposed to pay attention to the flashback this woman is a part of. Regardless, her boyfriend/husband arrives via train. He's back from war, and he's so happy he does his best Gene Kelly impression, by swinging around a streetlight.I can't state enough just how brilliant these little moments are. There's no dialogue between these unimportant NPCs, they don't factor into the plot, and yet they add so much. The two most recent FF games I played through were FF13 and FF13-2. The few times I ran into NPCs they're just...standing around. Sometimes they walk, and they say a line or two when I walk past, but that's usually about it. Actually, FF13-2 did have the kids that run around the beach, one of them trips a lot. It might not sound like much, but that little bit of life makes the experience a lot more believable. Complexity. The first Final Fantasy was practically Wizardry with an overhead view. Even then, it had numerous ideas that offered replay value. The most obvious one is the class system. Once you decided on your party, that was it. Whether you went with the traditional (Fighter, Monk, White Mage, Black Mage) the different (Thief, Thief, Red Mage, Red Mage) or the ridiculous (Four White Mages), you were stuck with that party until you won the game. FF1 was an altogether difficult entry, with numerous random encounters that could wipe you out. One of my most memorable party-wipes was when my party of 4 was killed by a handful of ghouls. Every round they did 1-2 damage, and every round they paralyzed everyone. That was about 25 years ago...sheesh.By the time FF4 came out, the random encounter was no longer a serious threat. I never saw the easier battles as a "dumbing down" of FF. These RPGs have numerous mechanics and design decisions to keep track of. What better way to drill this into the player's head than through actual combat? The battles are there so you can figure out how everything works. Look at this way: You're always getting a new party member, new spells, espers, materia, junctions, jobs, gambits, etc upon etc. So naturally, you'll want to try things out, and not get killed in the process. It's like a tutorial...without actually being a tutorial (though FF has plenty of those as well).Most of the depth and challenge in FF comes from taking away all of the stuff you receive. This difficulty has to be player-imposed, but it works wonders for extending the value of these games. FF7 is no different, as there are low-level runs, no materia runs, and so on. Even something as simple as choosing not to use limit-breaks can massively change the game. After all, once a party member takes enough damage, their fight command is replaced with limit. Now what? Hopefully that character learned mug, or has some items that do damage. Heck, you might have to kill them yourself so their meter will drain. Suddenly those bosses you meteorained through become a lot more interesting.The best part is, even if you play through FF7 and take everything that's given, it's still an enjoyable JRPG. This is due to pacing. Unless you're trying to max out everything, FF7 is a +/-30 hour game. That is PERFECT! I can not emphasize it enough. Those hours are going to be spent in various locales, doing a wide variety of things, and having a grand adventure. I can't tell you the number of RPGs that I've given up on, simply because nothing happens for 5-10 hours at a time. A game having 100s of hours of "content" just isn't a selling point for me anymore. FF7 moves quickly enough, and still tells you all you need to know in terms of story/characters. It isn't spectacularly written, but it's an effective story that is appropriately-paced. All of this is why I think Final Fantasy 7 deserves respect. It encompasses everything that makes JRPGs work. No really, I believe this game is an example of flawless execution. I mean, a game like Xenogears might have a better plot & more interesting characters (to me), but between disc 2, the platforming, and  t h e  s l o w - m o v i n g  t e x t  t h a t  c a u s e s  m y  b r a i n  t o  g o  n u m b, I regard it as a "more than the sum of its parts" kind of JRPG. Still, it's like I said waaaaay back, FF7 is probably not the best JRPG of all time. It does a pretty good job of making you think it is though.

content:
2016
												I came into this game without any nostalgia at all connected to it, and came out thinking it was a masterpiece. A lot of people will say it hasn't aged well, and I agree to a certain extent, but it's pretty easy to get past the parts that feels clunky and outdated. If anything, it just makes the game feel more charming. The world is cool and interesting, the gameplay is fun (allthough sometimes it can feel just a little bit tedious) and the story is absolutely fantastic. The writing focuses a lot on the characters, which I think is a great thing, personally. All the playable characters got a lot of attention and character building, which made me really care about them in the end, adding to the emotional roller coaster that is this game.There are some pretty deep themes in FINAL FANTASY VII, such as loss and identity, and life and death. This only adds to the world and story, and makes it a much more unique and interesting experience.It's a pretty dark and complex story, at least for the time it was concieved. It does however come off as a bit much at times, like a ridiculous scene in the early stages of the game, where the main character, Cloud, rides out of a large office building on a motorcycle, all while fending off enemy pursuers with a sword.Despite this and a few other scenes, the story is very interesting and keeps you invested until the very end.As someone who had never played this before a few weeks ago, I can see how this game became such an instant classic. I honestly consider this to be the best game i've ever played, and I want to recommend it to anyone, as long as you have the patience for the outdated gameplay and graphics.

content:
ber 1, 2014
												Game Title : Final Fantasy 7Developer: Squaresoft / Square EnixGenre: RPG / Turn Based / Not turn based you can turn if off.I first started playing Final Fantasy 7 when I was 8 years old. I loved everything about it the world, people and music amazing. This game was my first RPG and really set the bar for others. If you ever read about why Square has not made a remake they state it is because and I quote here. "CEO Yoichi Wada said that a remake of Final Fantasy VII will happen once the company makes a new Final Fantasy title that succeeds the seventh game in terms of quality and sales, something the company has to date failed to do". Think about that for a mintue this game was made in 1997 almost 20 years later no other game they made has yet to top it...Story: This game is set on earth in another place and time. A place where the planets very blood "The lifestream" discovered by a company called Shinra, INC. Shinra found a way to turn lifestream into a power source and built reactors all around the world sucking up the lifesteam and killing the planet. You are Cloud Strife "mercerany" hired by your old childhood friend Tifa to help her and AVALANCHE put a stop to it... this story unfolds into an epic tale of love that puts the very life of the planet in your hands.Game play: The gameplay is smooth and seemless you always know what you need to do next. If you ever get stuck there are many guides that will help you figure it all out.  Battling enemies is fun you can make it turn based, or set it to active (no turns) for a greater challenge. There are many very fun and challanging mini game series in this game. A motorcycle challenge, submarine battles, snowboarding, and a few others. This game supports controllers I played the whole game with a Xbox 360 controller.Graphics: For the time period 1997 the graphics were soild the few in game movies have really nice graphics. Otherwise it's mostly blocky textures. There are graphics mods out that give the game a more updated feel. They are hard to install but, pay off if you get them to work.Audio: The music now updated is very nice! One of the only games where I used to play it just to listen to it.Overall: It has everything a rpg fan loves. A great story with wonderful music, the people all have backgrounds your can really get into. There are many side quests and challenges. You can't forget the Chocobos everyone loves those for dinner... I mean to race them.Story 10/10Gameplay 10/10Graphics 7/10 for 1997 10/10 if you can mod itSoundtrack 10/10Difficulty 6/10I give this game a 10/10 ( Square would make a killing if they remade this game with current graphics)

content:
30, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is one of my favorite games of all time.  I had the original PC version back in the day and it ran flawlessly if I remember correctly.  I played it with my Gravis gamepad.  Again, with no problems.  This version is a disappointment all around.  The first thing you will be required to do is to create an account with Sqaure.  Makes no sense at all, but hey.  Still, it is an annoyance.  Once I finally got the game fired up, I immediately started having problems with my gamepad.  The cursor was flying all over the place.  I had to download a profile for Pinnacle to fix that and the fact that a few of the buttons would not respond at all.  Again, an annoyance.  Despite this effort my character still wants to walk to the left much of the time.  This I cannot seem to fix.  Sure, I can just plow forward and try to ignore it, but it still detracts from the game.  Lots of people have complained about the music or the fact that the graphics look terrible on current HD monitors.  That really does not bother me at all.  The same great gameplay is there if you can get to it.  The horrible controls completely wreck it.  A person much wiser than me, who also owns this "updated" version, told me that it was a better idea to just use a psx emulator to run this game if you really want to enjoy it again.  He was right.  Square totally dropped the ball on this one.  They have pretty much dumped all over the game that literally put them on the map.  I am definitely NOT saying that Final Fantasy VII is not a great game.  It is.  This is just not the version you want to play if you want to enjoy it.

content:
er 26, 2013
												A classic from the Playstation 1 era. This is one of the first RPG games I ever played and has always set the standard of what I expect from an RPG. It features turn based, but active combat, a fun and more-or-less easy to follow story, and decent characters and personalities though some border on the cliche. Finaly Fantasy 7 has a good amount of side quests and minigames that can eat up plenty of time. From snowboarding to breeding and racing chocobos the handful of side quests and metagames can keep you entertained for quite a while.                I found that, as with almost all RPGs I play, one of my favorite things to do is collect all the strongest magics and weapons. There are monsters you can encounter that are even stronger than the last boss at the end of the main story. On top of that there are magic abilities that, if you have the patience to level them up, can make the final boss a walk in the park. Getting these weapons and magics require a great deal of grinding though, which is someting I find to be rather offputting. Squeezing every last ounce of gameplay from this title will probably take you somewhere in the neighborhood of 70 hours if youre the occational gamer like me.              Since it's initial release the game has not really aged well. If youre looking for a top-notch Final Fantsy expierience I would point you to one of the newer titles. It's kind of hard to look at the old graphics in high resolution. To help this they have an "original graphics" mode for people like me. It keeps the display to 480x640, but without the inherit funnyness of a SDtv set you still see plenty of jaggies and protruding polygons. The graphics didnt stop me from playing through one of my old favorites though.              Another gripe I have about the age is the clunky controls when roaming about but it's nothing you cant get used to. The button layout can be a tad confusing on the keyboard. If you happen to have a gamepad it eases this considerably, but you're probably going to have to spend a moment remapping the default controls-- no biggie.            One of my favorite aspects about the steam version is the cloud saving. True: its usless if you dont have an internet connection where you want to play. But I like the ability to play on my PC, go wherever, and pick the game right back up on my laptop. Aside from that there is also a "character booster" if you get stuck...or want to be a badass. I have not used the feature mainly because I forgot my square-enix login stuff moments after i made it.               Its not particularly weak in any areas but isnt as deep in character skill devlopment as I would like sometimes. Rather than molding your character(s) into what you want them to be, you have to play to each character's strengths-- again, no biggie.               Theres no voiceover, which is a huge plus for me. The story is good, characters are likeable, the gameplay is solid, and its good on length. It's probably 20 hours on the game clock on a casual playthough if you ignore endgame badass equipment, skills, and sidequests. All-in-all its worth it if it's on sale, but if you just want a stroll down memory lane you might be better off digging out the old PS1.

number of helpful: 92 of 124 people (74%) found this review helpful28 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												I think after spending 200+ hours on this game, it's time to write a review.You guys ok with this? If not, so sorry (sarcasm)The PC version of FFVII! A great game gets a great PC port with a little graphic upscale on the side.Pros:This game is magic. Absolute gold. (And I don't even like FF games.)Fun to play (I literally spent 200+ hours on this. I think I might be a bit biased)Minigames. Chocobos are fun to ride around on.It will literally keep you busy for hours.Controls well. (Although, I did not use a controller and I'm not sure if controllers can be used. I prefer keyboards anyway.)Music is sweet.Cons:Master Tonberry (Stab stab)Ruby WeaponEmerald WeaponRandom EncountersAnalysis:Upon first glance of Final Fantasy VII, I almost blew it off. Steam Christmas sales changed my mind quickly.I picked it up and started it. The beginning was slow. Not slow enough to deter me from the glory that I would experience later on though. You start off as Cloud, an edgy, roided up, Ex-SOLDIER mercenary. You are hired by AVALANCHE to rig one of the mako reactors to explode. You do this. Easy stuff.Story continues (I'm not going to spoil anything. Just look at this review and determine if you want to buy it.)You will find enemies that you will absolutely hate. I'm quite sure my least favorites were the parasites and Master Tonberry. The story will tug a few heartstrings. I choked up a bit when a couple things happened. There'll be some twists and turns that you might not expect (Unless you were played the original. Then enjoy this masterpiece again, friend.)There'll be some goofs and gaffs. The characters are unique and their dialogue is entertaining. DON'T TOUCH THE RED THING IN THE DESERT. Still not going to spoil anything... but when you get to the ending, Be prepared to have some of your soul ripped out of you because it's so gosh darn good.Conclusion:The game is almost perfect. It's flaws will and have been pointed out, but I'm not here for that. I like the game for what it is and I highly recommend buying it. It's been worth the 200+ hours and I definitely got my money's worth.

content:
er 30, 2016
												1) You DO NOT NEED TO BE ONLINE 24/7 TO PLAY. You just need to have internet while you make a square account. Then once you're logged in, go to 'FF7 Launcher Settings' and disable 'Cloud Saving'. There you go. FF7 will never need to be connected to the internet again.   I point this out because I keep reading reviews that say you need to be online 24/7 DRM blah blah... and its completely untrue. It put me off of buying the game for awhile. Screw that. Now you know.   2) They updated the character models and enemies and they did a good job. Its a perfect mix of old and new, slanted towards old. The models are improved, not changed. And if for some reason you hate it, in the launcher theres a toggle. You can have the exact Ps1 graphics if you want. But once you switch you'll want to go back to the updated version, trust me on that.3) Check out all the different mods for the steam version of FF7. Depending on how far you want to go, you can mod this games graphics pretty hard.   TLDR: If you played FF7 as a kid and loved it then get this. 6 bucks is a steal.   TLDR#2: You don't need to be online 24/7 to play. That's a myth. So don't worry.

												What to say about FF7 that hasn't already been said? No, it's not the best game ever. Yes it has flaws, yes, the graphics are outdated, and a big part of his success comes from when it was released...That being said, and while I can't deny the fact that I have a huge bias, since it's the first video game I've ever played...The thing that strikes me when I play again is this game's generosity, in pretty much every aspect.- generous in term of longevity, the story is huge, long, with twists, takes you in many places. It's a game from an era where games where not necessarily designed with replayability in mind, and that frankly still doesn't need it.- generous in its gameplay, with a really nice system allowing you to think about your group roles, and that though about the fun part more than the efficient part. Also, an incredible number of mini-games introduced in the story to shake things a little, and later available as full blown mini-games (snowboard, submarine, Fort Condor,...)- generous in its music, with lots of soundtracks very well used to illustrate each place, or returning characters.So, yeah. There are a lot to be done, and the beauty of it is that it isn't forced upon you. It's a game where the devs did all they could to make the experience even more enjoyable, but didn't shove it in your throat.As I said, it's not perfect. But it will forever stay the perfect exemple of a video game done right, with the player's enjoyement always in mind.

content:
er 10, 2013
												While Final Fantasy VII is a great (if very dated) game at its core, this has every symptom of a poor console port.  It's just a repack of the original port from over a decade ago.  Some things that show it's an effortless port:-Characters faces are bugged.  All eyes are open, even if they're sleeping. All mouths are gaping, which looks ridiculous after a time.-Controller mapping is awful (XBOX 360 controller).  The D-pad can't be mapped, which makes battle menus a pain.  You'll often accidentally slide to the side and choose Defend when trying to scroll down the menu.  R2/L2 can't be mapped.  The OK button decides to go "turbo mode" frequently and skip dialog.-No 16:9 mode (I don't count 4:3 awfully stretched to 16:9)-Lots of odd crashes.  If you tab out of fullscreen, it will crash.  If your controller idles off while tabbed out in windowed mode, the game will crash.  For a non-autosaving game with 90s-style spread out save points, this is infuriating.-If it can't sync your cloud saves, you can't save the game unless you exit and turn off cloud saving (losing your progress in the offing).If you played this in the 90s, and you want to give it a nostalgic run, go for it.  But know that you're going to have to accept a lot of lousy-port-isms.  If you didn't play this in the 90s, the dated graphics, old gameplay mechanics and PC quirks will make you regret the purchase. I wish I could give it a 6.5 instead of a "Not recommended" because it is still fun, and it's great to go back and play.

number of helpful: 27 of 31 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												New to the Final Fantasy series, I decided to pick this game up after hearing lots of good things about it. Final Fantasy VII is one of those iconic games which you hear so much talk about, that you have to play it in order to see if it matches what people say. And does it live up to expectations? Well, mostly.Story:FF7's story suprised me, as it was quite different to what I had expected, although not in a bad way. From what I'd heard beforehand, I was used to thinking of Final Fantasy 7 as this dark, brooding story set in a dystopian futuristic city, and while this holds true for the first couple of hours, there is so much more to it. As mentioned, FF7 is often seen as quite dark, but in reality it's a game which never takes itself to seriously, and still retains a sense of fun. The story itself is long and developped (it took me around 60 hours to beat the main story alone), and covers several mature themes. I have to say that I found the main story really engrossing, even if I'd heard some spoilers beforehand. If their was one criticism to be had with the story, it's that the latter half of the game doesn't quite manage to meet the standard of the first half, with the plot becoming a bit too convoluted, and difficult to follow.GameplayThe gameplay in Final Fantasy VII is good, but nothing spectacular. Being an JRPG, a good deal of gameplay is taken up by turnbased battles. The combat system is simple enough for beginners, but also has enough technique for more experienced players. This makes for several fun battles, although a large number of random encounters, as well as summon attack cutscenes which can take up to two minutes to play out, can make them seem a bit repetitive. I enjoyed the battles for the most part although some of them towards the end of the game, I found very frustrating .As well as battles there are also several minigames such as motorbike chases, or snowboarding which you can try out. These can be fun, but I didn't try them out much. Outside of battles and minigames, you will travel across the world and explore caves, and towns. This is easier said than done, as the static backgrounds can be quite hard to traverse.GraphicsIt's no secret that Final Fantasy VII's graphics are a bti dated, with some characters looking like lego, but I genuinely didn't mind them that much. They have been sharpened for this release, and some of the battles actually look quite decent. There are several cutscenes as well, which look quite good for the time.MusicIf there's one thing which is easy to agree on about Final Fantasy VII, it's that it has great music. From killer battle tracks, to heart wrenching leitmotifs, this game has some of the best and most memorable music I've seen in a game. Mr. Uematsu, I salute you.VerdictFinal Fantasy VII is an amazing game with a memorable story, some fun battles, and a killer soundtrack. Even the occasional frustrating moment, doesn't stop this from being an incredible game.10/10

number of helpful: 26 of 31 people (84%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
5, 2016
The game that sold the PlayStation Final Fantasy VII is adored by young and old around the world. The game's various versions have sold over 11 million units as of 2015, and it remains popular to this day. If you've never heard of it, then where the hell have you been?!The story has an excellent premise, as evinced by the extensive efforts of Square Enix to milk the universe of all its worth (spin-offs include Crisis Core, Dirge of Cerberus, and even a movie, Advent Children, among others). You start with Cloud Strife (employed as a mercenary) and long-time friend Tifa Lockheart as members of eco-terrorist group AVALANCHE, under the command of Barrett Wallace. The underlying belief of the group is that the planet's life energy is being consumed by Shinra Corporation's reactors, slowly but surely destroying the planet. The group organise attacks against the reactors in the belief they are saving the planet. These events are eventually dwarfed by a new threat to the planet: Sephiroth.The game has done well over the years thanks to a whole plethora of reasons that help make it come alive, and it often stays alive in the minds of gamers long after players have experienced it. The engaging story, of which I have only touched upon here, is littered with so many twists and turns and shocking discoveries that you'll likely be dizzy with awesomeness by the end of it.Gameplay is much the same as previous titles, using the standard random encounter mechanic we all know and love to initiate fights with monsters or people. Equipment is limited to one weapon and one armor at a time, but these can have various materia slots. Materia is crystallised Mako, or lifestream energy, and is the source of many abilities and enhancements characters can make use of in the game, not the least of which is magic spells, summons, auto-abilities and stat boosts. Materia can be levelled, and once mastered can spawn a duplicate materia, allowing much customisation and experimentation.The game really is an emotional rollercoaster. The characters are a lot more fully realised than many of those in previous titles in the series - Barrett's concern for Marlene, Tifa's concern for Cloud ... even some of the Turks inspire our empathy at times (eg, Reno and Rude deciding they are 'off-duty' in regard to orders to search for Cloud, after working together briefly). Cloud's cross-dressing scene is good for a laugh. People are killed. Truths are learnt. A good game is a game that holds our attention, and that is what FFVII and its characters do as we strive to know more about what is happening and why. Indeed, the shock death of one of our own team members definitely added to the game's infamy. Most of you already know who I'm talking about. And perhaps because of this, Sephiroth is often lauded as one of, if not the, greatest game villain of all time. I know my own feelings are a mix of admiration and hate when I think of him.The art style was a leap ahead in its time, but in today's world of newest releases it does have a dated feel to it, with chunky 3D graphics on par with much of the earliest games to implement 3D graphics. On the PC version little has changed, although it has been criticised for its lower quality graphics, installation and framerate problems. I did not experience any problems personally, and have come to not expect vast improvements in framerate from FF re-releases.Some would say the PS version is more impressive - I myself cannot say as I never got around to playing that version. It does seem as though Square Enix has only done the bare minimum to get the game to work on PC - a trait shared by many FF PC ports, much to the disgust of expectant PC FF fans.The music is excellent, but many of its most loved tracks have been reworked for Advent Children, and it is these versions I enjoy the most, especially One-Winged Angel. As it happens, the FFVII version is also composer Nobuo Uematsu's favourite from the soundtrack, and his favourite battle theme from any Final Fantasy game.Some cons I believe are worth noting:- Cheap final boss fight, impossible to lose- A minority might find the plot very confusing to grasp as more facts are brought to lightI would have listed the game's linear nature, but this isn't so bad when you consider it as a trade-off for good story. Also to make up for this are the game's various mini games, helping to beef up an already impressive game. There is a barrel pushing game in the Sector 5 Church, a 'squats' mini game at the Wall Market, a sneaking game in the Shinra Building, in addition to various mini games that can be played at the Gold Saucer, including G Bike, the Fort Condor strategy minigame, and of course the chocobo racing game, among others. Some of these are easy while others can be hard.With the inclusion of Steam achievements, there is plenty for the aspiring completionist to aim for. Be sure to add this piece of gaming history to your library, you won't regret it.

content:
ber 12, 2013
												7/10 In 1997, one of the most influential, inspiring, and standard-setting RPG's ever was released: Final Fantasy 7. In fact, it was the #1 best selling game in the series' history, and one of the best selling games of the time. FF7 "sold the Playstation" (according to Wiki). It pushed the petty PS1 to astronomical levels above and beyond what it was intended for. Square had developed a game so indepth, so massive, that it took THREE discs just to contain it all! Great writing, beautiful story telling, breath-taking art, and a soundtrack that will sweep your mind away and invoke so many emotions are the words to describe this....AND SQUARE FREAKIN' RUINS IT WITH THIS PC RELEASE! First of all, DRM. Yap, DRM...FOR A SINGLE PLAYER GAME! I almost saw past  this, then the unimaginable happened: THEY CHANGED THE SOUND EFFECTS AND THE MUSIC FROM THE ORIGINAL. UN...FORGIVABLE. The new music and sounds are literally painful. A guide here on Steam shows how to get the original music, but what was Square thinking?! If you can get the work around for the music to work (or use youtube like me), see past the DRM, and fight the weird PC controls, one of the greatest games ever made lies hidden behind it all. I don't even know if I should recommend this or not. Maybe go for the PS version instead. I feel so let down.

er 28, 2016
												It's FF7, do I even need to say anything more than that? Well, for one thing, does all the hype buzzing around this 90's big budget JRPG title actually stack up to the experience of playing it? Admittedly, as a teenager when FF7 first came out, I could never get that far into the game because heart-crushingly my second hand FF7 disc two would not ever properly load, hence I never made it past the first disc.. So, considering this was pretty much my first time playing through the game, in some sense my opinion about FF7 is as unbiased as one can get for a RPG of this stature and age. I can safely say, that yes, this is a great experience! While FF7's combat may seem dull at first glance, it's actually rather deep if you dig into it and if you're like me and enjoy trying out new build combos then it's definitely worth poking around and experimenting with. There are several extensive side quests based around finding "secret" items that will make you and your party stronger.. The game's plot is done well, mainly due to the strong characters.. The game slowly leads you along each character's past, but never fully gives you everything.. This type of story approach kept me constantly wanting more!So yeah, go play this game!

content:
er 8, 2015
												This game is the peak in the videogame industry, you have the best plot ever made but with some missing things that you have to guess. It contains the most known spoiler in the videogame history, and one of the most known antagonist as well...and he is not evil just because no reason, it has a very deep reason.STORY/PLOT 10/10The best story in a videogame. Deep plot involving: Contamination problems, fighting a nemesis (which you don't want to kill, just make him come to reason), discovery extra things in the story, the saddest spoilerS (yeah one in the middle and one near the end, but it is better described in Crisis Core).CHARACTERS 10/10The best antagonist in a videogame, it's not "bad" for no reason, and over time you don't want to kill him, just understand his reasons and stop him from his main objetive.You could think that you have more developed characters than others (I'm talking about their past) but when you do all their extra things you know you have been mistaken (even with the optional characters)COMBAT SYSTEM 9/10Of course the combat system is static, but imagine being the first FF having animations in the battles (attacking, preparing attacks, covering allies, etc, and the bosses as well). You can equip everyone with any materia, the only differences among them are the limits, some stats and some equipment of course. Some summons could be anoying to watch (specially Knights of the Round). Once you reach high lvls and equipment/materias there is no more challenge than Weapons (optional bosses spreaded over the map)GRAPHICS 9/10I know that some videogames had better graphics back then, but this was the first FF with: a) 3d characters/enemies (with a proper appearance for your chars inbattle...no more dwarf chars against well drawn non-animated enemies)b) 3d to 2d rendered spaces, you could think it's not good, but it gave them the opportunity to show a lot of detailed things within the places, and you don't have the same houses/buildings structures over and over in a town/city anymore.c)being a pre rendered 2d place, you don't have popping textures which they were present in almost every game in that gen (it was normal then)GAMEPLAY 10/10I did split "gamplay" from "combat system" for three reasons:First: no more party splits to solve puzzles (If you played FFVI you know how anoying it could be without no-encounters).Second: the 3d map now looks the most alive map in a FF so far, so you really feel like you are discovering new places every time, and now you have more vehicles.Third: a lot of minigames in the game, defending a fortress, doing sport, chocobos(very anoying if you don't have a proper chocobo), snow, motorbike, etc...DIALOG 10/10It has very deep conversations sometimes, everyone has something to say, maybe the only "bad" thing in this game is the translation (at least the spanish translation is known as the worst translation ever made)MUSIC 10/10Nobuo Uematsu made a very good job here, this soundtrack not only has a lot of memorable songs, it has the sephiroth theme, used in the next FFVII games, and (of course) KH sephiroth battle. I think I can say that there is not another song that identifies a videogame character like this song does.CONCLUSIONThe best PSX game (I know, the closests to this one are MGS and CTR). The best plot in a videogame. OPINION ABOUT THE UPCOMING REMAKE:I played and enjoyed this masterpiece a lot of times. I totally agree with a remake, and I would like to see a new combat system, because I have the old combat system in this game.I want new stories within the game, new characters if they are needed or showing more content that we could have not seen before.People think that a bad remake could destroy the game, but I don't think so, the FFVII was done and finished 20 years ago, you are not touching that game, you are making a new one, if it is a bad remake, it doesn't matter, you have the old game forever, and even better, you could be the guy which always says: "the original was better", "if I wanted to play FFVII I wouldn't play this ♥♥♥♥", etc.

number of helpful: 33 of 47 people (70%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 30, 2014
												This is "The" Final Fantasy game for a lot of people. The holy grail. The best of them all. The pinicle of the series.Do I think that? No, actually, I don't. I liked IX more than VII personally. However, I do still enjoy this game and I do recommend it. Don't let my play time fool you, I've got 3 complete playthroughs under my belt on the PS1 and I recently purchased this PC version so I can always have it on hand.This game holds a special place in a lot of people's hearts because it was the very first 3D final fantasy game and it has a story that hooks you early, and keeps you going throughout.It's very important to keep in mind that this game came out in 1997. 17 years ago at the time of this review. That's nearly two decades, and this PC release of the original PS1 game is by and large the exact same graphically. They did slightly upgrade the character models and portraits, but they're still just as blocky as they were then.A downside with the PC release is the MIDI sound files are not the best of quality. That can be modded though, if you're feeling rather adventurous as modding is not a built in feature so it takes following some guides to know what files to replace and in what folders. The graphics can also be modded to make the game look more recent than it really is, but with these you have to be a bit more careful as the most popular set of mods will make you unable to gain achievements in the game or use the cloud saves. That is because the mods were created for the original PC release of the game, and not this much more recent Steam release and no one has gone through the effort of porting all those mods over to work with the Steam version to keep achievements active.The game itself has a standard RPG story that you'll come to expect from Final Fantasy games, and as you probably know it is highly regarded by many. VI and VII are by and large the absolute most popular Final Fantasy games, and that's likely always to be the case. I really don't want to spoil anything so I won't go into specifics.A unique feature of the game is its materia system, which is a system where your weapon and armor has slots in which you can equip materia that gives you access to a specific spell. This allows you to take your characters and build them up with exactly the spells you want them to have, but you can switch it up to meet any paticular challenge without any penalties. This is particularly nice because it allows you to put the characters you most care about into your active party and not be punished for doing so. Characters still maintain a unique identity through their limit break skills. The only exception being that through much of the game you are required to use the main character, Cloud, but you're free to pick and choose the other two fairly early in the game.For a very early PS1 game, it still features a lot of content like an overworld map, travel by airships, mini-games, optional super bosses, etc. Now, while it has an overworld map don't be fooled into thinking it's open world. It isn't. Like most of the Final Fantasy games it is by and large linear, but at about the halfway to 2/3 mark you do start to get more freedom in where you go. It's linear in that while you can wonder around the map, natural barriers prevent you from going too far from where you are suppose to get until you advance the story and unlock new modes of transportation.Overall I do think this is a good game, and worth playing through at least once if you have not done so. If you've already played through the game once before on a different system and are just curious what the changes are, I'd probably skip this as the changes in graphics is minimal.
