content:
er 22, 2016
												What more can be said about this game that you probably haven't already heard? It's going on almost 20 years old and highly regarded as one of the classic JRPGs to set the standard for quality, story, innovation, battle mechanics, and more. If you've heard about this game and never played it, there's a reason. It has some of the most interesting settings and characters, even by today's standards. When this game released in 1997, the graphics were hailed as some of the best out there. Although they may not hold up to that these days, they are still colorful and fun. In all honesty, I still think they're good.If you have not played this game, do yourself a favor and buy it. I consider it the best Final Fantasy in the series, and I've played almost all of them.

												If you haven't played Final Fantasy 7, then you probably don't like JRPGs anyways. That said, it's probably the quintessential posterchild for modern day JRPGs, and one of the games that helped bring them to the mainstream. Final Fantasy 7 is easily one of the better JRPGs ever made, but also one of the most overrated. Also keep in mind, this game requires you to be always online, for DRM purposes, but gives no real benefits to this requirement other than Achievements. If you are wanting to play a JRPG, and are unable to find an original disc of this game, then this is the best alternative.

												I didn't play video games as a child so I missed out on a lot of classics. Had a bit of trouble with the version on the PSN, tried using an emulator on my laptop but it kept giving me audio trouble and I just felt frustrated and bored.I bought this  version because I wanted to play the rest of the story myself and the remake announcement reminded me how much I love Aerith. I replayed all my progress from the past few months in a few days.The PC version is great, really easy to play with a gamepad. I didn't miss save states or any of the extras from the emulated version. It really sucked me into the story for the first time. Initially I was frustrated with the pre-rendered backgrounds but they grew on me. Very beautiful. It's really easy to get pulled into this universe.Gripes:I'm annoyed you have to make a square enix account to play the game. The site goes down all the time. The cloud saving rarely works and I reccomend turning it off if you are going to be saving a lot (like grinding on the world map etc). Also I didn't use the character boost because I didn't need it. I may try it on another playthrough though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 8, 2013
												Underneath the crusty PC port is the game I love, shining like a jewel. But, with cloudsaving that, more often that not, doesn't work, an immensely rocky entry because of an account requirement for a single-player  game that should not have been a concern even months after launch on Steam, and multiple progress stealing crashes, FF7 for PC is not a game I can recommend, even as a diehard fan. It is just too much hassle, both in and out of the game.Update: Not really as upset with the game, but I still don't recommend the game, even to my friends. People who love Final Fantasy will play this regardless, just as I have. I don't encounter nearly as many crashes as I used to because I play it on a stronger computer, but have still encountered some. Cloudsaving is still a consistent problem, however. Though it works more than it doesn't, the times it doesn't are frustrating and can go on for as long as an entire day. The irony in this is that the player requires an account or linking of Facebook info, in part, because of this feature. To force a player to go to such lengths just to play a game that never required this in the first place for a feature that works so infrequently is not a good justification. This is not even mentioning that Steam has these functions covered, should the effort be put in. In text, it seems like a poor port.

content:
1, 2013
												FF7 was the most groundbreaking RPG of its era. It was the edge that gave Sony dominance in the console market, the hammerblow to Nintendo's pride and the straw that broke Sega's back. It represents the pinnacle of Sqauresoft's history and in the eyes of many, no single player RPG has come close since. It also spawned one of the most recognisable bad guys in gaming history. The heavy anime style gives it a very Japanese feel, Nobuo's music is fantastic, from the energetic guitar based battle themes to the heartwrenchingly sorrowful Aerith's theme. A game that excited a generation, filling our heads with unforgettable memories of an awesome, immersive experience. It's a must play for any hardcore RPG fanatic.

content:
29, 2014
												So after reading a lot of reviews about all the trouble people have had with this game and with square I checked out all the positive reviews and figured it was worth a buy on sale. This game brings me back to my high school days and I have beaten it many times. I still have the original for my PS but the first disk is damaged and wont let me play in Midgar.Anyway, I have had zero issues with setting up my square account and it only takes one log in to play so that hasn't been an issue for me at all. I said "no thank you" to having cloud saves available and I will never use the character boost, to me it is a pretty dumb addition to the game.The cleaned up graphics took some getting used to and the controls on the keyboard are a little funky for sure so if you can set up a controller I would recomend it. That being said the characters now do look nice without funky angles shooting out of thier bodies. Music sounds great I am guessing it has been fixed since so many complained about it. If you loved this game when you were younger or want to play it now because you never have and it is on sale, go for it! Still an amazing game and I love that I can play it for what seems like the 100th time and still love every second.

content:
y 12, 2016
												With the upcoming remake of Final Fantasy VII there will definitely be mixed reviews about which is better. the remake or the original? The least any newcomer to the Final Fantasy franchise can do is to play the original first before any potential shortcomings the remake may have to offer.For most the 1997 release was their first Final Fantasy and is therefore special to them. Upon replaying FFVII on Steam I had such an overwealming nostalgia which quite honestly surprised me. I could remember everything so clearly even after almost 20 years since first playing it. Everything was the same as I had imagined it even back then, though I will say that this updated version has a few things which had been changed. Certain dialogue and so on, though I don't think this is such a major issue to many.The Materia system is still top notch, though now I am certainly more cautious with what I use instead of throwing everything on a character just because I had it, as I would have done on my first playthrough. Plenty of mini games to keep one entertained when sick of grinding or just want to take a break from the story. The battle system was exciting for its time, especially with the added Limit Breaks which were a huge improvement on VI's Desperation Attacks. which were quite frankly rubbish. The fact you could save the special attack for a better time as well as evolve them into better ones by using them was a reason to try out every character, just to see what they did. With the new release, the old battle system will certainly be dead and buried so we can probably say goodbye to many of the epic moves and abilities we once encountered.The soundtrack? 11/10. Nuff said.If anything, this is one of my least favourite Final Fantasies in the franchise, though it was my first. Even though I prefer most of the others, this truly is a special game that will not only challenge you, but become a part of you in the process. It can be a bit of an eyesore to look at in this day and age, but if you love a story rich game then there's nothing really stopping you from buying this game.

content:
er 28, 2013
												There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

content:
1, 2013
												FF7 was the most groundbreaking RPG of its era. It was the edge that gave Sony dominance in the console market, the hammerblow to Nintendo's pride and the straw that broke Sega's back. It represents the pinnacle of Sqauresoft's history and in the eyes of many, no single player RPG has come close since. It also spawned one of the most recognisable bad guys in gaming history. The heavy anime style gives it a very Japanese feel, Nobuo's music is fantastic, from the energetic guitar based battle themes to the heartwrenchingly sorrowful Aerith's theme. A game that excited a generation, filling our heads with unforgettable memories of an awesome, immersive experience. It's a must play for any hardcore RPG fanatic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 20, 2015
												What could I ever write here that hasn't been said before. I remember putting in 70+ hours into this game when it first arrived to Playstation back in 1997. What I can say is that the PC port, while not the HD remake we always hoped for, provides a little more polish than it's 1997 counterpart and remains a distinct landmark in the Final Fantasy series.Graphics & Story: For the era it was produced in, FF7 had compelling graphics along with full motion video and a great cast of unique and interesting characters. Famous scenes such as Sephiroth's walk through the flame engulfed Nibelheim or the fateful moment in the Forgotten Capital provide the gamer with the type of immersion that has tried to be replicated through numerous games following FF7's release. Music: With Nobuo Uematsu at the helm, there was no doubt that the soundtrack would be any less than great. One-Winged Angel is one of the most memorable compositions in Video Game history and Aerith's theme provided the perfect emotional tone for that pivotal moment in the Forgotten Capital.Again not much more I can say but that I can't wait for the HD remake - 10/10Update: Mar 16, 2015Finally finished my 100% achievement file. Hoping we hear something regarding a sequel or remake in 2017 on the game's 20th anniversary. Give Final Fantasy VII a try if you've never played it before. This classic is certainly worth the time.Update: June 16, 2015Well holy hell....the remake is happening.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 20, 2014
												It's FINAL FANTASY FRIGGIN SEVEN. What the hell else do you need to know? It's still one of the best JRPGs of all time, and the game that would come to define an entire genre for over 10 years. Ignore whatever preconceptions you might have had about this game being overrated, or any kind of bad taste left in your mouth from the mostly-terrible Compilation of Final Fantasy VII. This game really is as good as you've heard, from the tight and expansive battle system, the highly customizable characters, the massive world filled with nooks and crannies to explore, and, of course, a great story. In Final Fantasy VII, you play the role of Cloud, an ex-SOLDIER working with a resistance company called AVALANCHE to take down his former employers, the Shin-Ra corporation. Along the way, you'll encounter giant rideable chickens, swords the size of your house and then some, more existential crises than you can wave a giant unwieldy sword at, and, of course, a whole pile of homoeroticism. The PC port could be better, but it's still pretty decent. It doesn't really matter, because this is a game you NEED to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												A classic.  Chances are if you're buying this you've played it already.  If not, well you'll get to see what all us thirty-somethings are talking about.  There are options to run at a higher resolution and dither the textures and stuff like that... but there isn't much point.  This game has polygons and fmv's and whatnot - but it's really born from a 16-bit era design philosophy.  Keep that in mind while playing - it's more about the story than the presentation - and that story is a parable for the true struggle of our age, which is why it resonates with so many people.  The irony here is that Squenix is behaving more and more like the evil corporation in its cautionary tale...Worth the 40 or so hours, I say.  Get it.  Run it at low rez.  Punch Square-Enix in the face for big-brothering you before letting you play.  (An account is required!)  Wish you had just kept your Playstation and curse the death of privacy.  Square:  Either you die Squaresoft... or you live long enough to see yourself become Square-Enix...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 22
												I was one of those people who never played the game when it released, as I did not own a PS1. I now see why so many people list it as "greatest game ever". I wouldn't rate it as my "greatest video game ever" but it is certainly a very good game. My first experience with the game was around 1999 and even then I felt like these graphics were pretty dated compared to games such as Ocarina of Time, but the gameplay still holds up well in 2017. I have not finished the game yet but have put in a lot of hours, and so far the story is very good, and the gameplay itself has held up well. If you're a younger gamer I'm not sure if you'll be able to appreciate the highly 1990s nature of this game, but I grew up on Genesis/SNES/N64 and can say that this is definitely one of the games of its generation that have aged well.For the people complaining about the Square Enix servers, I created my account when I first started the game and immediately unchecked the "Cloud Saves" option in settings, and have never had an issue with trying to play the game other than one crash when I was near the end of the "Disc 1" (of 3) content of the original release.

												FF7, too many words to describe how awesome this game is - Lets begin.1, In my lifetime i've bought this game 4 - 5 times now, this is because PS2 games were the easiest things to lose as a child for some reason, one was from the Square Enix store and their Cee-loud services but no key for steam and once again on steam because #Enix couldn't come up with steam keys.2. The amout of mods available for this game to make it into HD is astonishing, 16GB but astonishing - I have yet to install these mods yet but once i do i shall be uploading videos or some ♥♥♥♥, i'm not entirely sure but enough about me and mods - the game right?Final Fantasy has a way of destroying the ♥♥♥♥ out of your time, you play the game at 9AM and you get off at 8AM, its just one of those games that gets you instantly hooked, the storyline and plot is a bit iffy but once you're towards the end it will all make sense, sorta. If you've played any other Final Fantasy Game that isn't Vincents offspring or Crisis Core - You will know, this is a pretty original Final Fantasy.Alot of people love the movie because of the game even if neither of them are any relevance to eachother besides the characters and summonings + Sephiroth Battle, speaking of Sephiroth battle - Let me make this crystal clear if i can - how can every boss you encounter me so mutated then you meet sephiroth and he's just stupidely mutated then at the very end {SPOILER} You hit a 0 and he dies, sweet, dramatic ending to a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fightBesides all that, alot of people have found exploits and random things about the game in which the average person wouldn't look for, this is always fun to explore on youtube or google. I do recommend this game because I've never personally bought the same game more than twice and usually thats for a friend so for me to have bought this for 4 - 5 in a row now - Pretty astonishing.But i know you guys don't know me, this is a review for the game so ♥♥♥♥ you. :D<3UPDATE 17/06/15 - So i herd you like re-males, it would appear that this game is being remade.on next gen, FF7; this beautiful game is going to make me cry at night now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
1, 2014
												The visuals are great for the time, the soundtrack was and still is absolute dynamite, and it is rich full of culture (seriously, go read the actual wikipedia page on 'Sephiroth').But bottom line, this game has not aged well at all. Majority of enemy encounters can be dispatched by holding down the O button.  You can't strategically use your Limit breaks in combat as you're forced to use them whenever they happen to pop up.  And 90% of the time, characters are all functionally identical besides "melee or ranged".Materia was criminally undercooked, there's not a lot to it. Something as simple as making Cloud levels materia faster, but will cause it to be weaker in the long run, would have helped.  Or some kind of mechanic where like: Tifa adds extra Agility stats to a materia as it levels up, so that can be swapped onto other characters to help out their stats.  Something to make me think about my party, how it's growing, what lineup I'm running, and how often.It's not always clear where I'm supposed to go, or what I'm supposed to do.  Seriously, how was I supposed to know I had to be looking for a battery for that lift thing, or that I'm supposed to pick some (seemingly) unrelated text option for that guard to unlock the next zone.  Trial-and-error, or just wondering around talking to everyone hoping they tell you something useful does not make for good game design.  I wont fault the story's execution as it was standard for the time, but the endless text-dumps aren't helping.I don't hate this game, and I'm not being deliberately provocative.  This game is just not nearly as amazing as people would have you believe, it could have been so much more.  I acknowledge that this game is totally a part of history, and deserves all the recognition for being groundbreaking (it was).  But this is not the greatest game ever made, it's not even the greatest Final Fantasy, not by a longshot.

												If you haven't played Final Fantasy 7, then you probably don't like JRPGs anyways. That said, it's probably the quintessential posterchild for modern day JRPGs, and one of the games that helped bring them to the mainstream. Final Fantasy 7 is easily one of the better JRPGs ever made, but also one of the most overrated. Also keep in mind, this game requires you to be always online, for DRM purposes, but gives no real benefits to this requirement other than Achievements. If you are wanting to play a JRPG, and are unable to find an original disc of this game, then this is the best alternative.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
												FF7 was the most groundbreaking RPG of its era. It was the edge that gave Sony dominance in the console market, the hammerblow to Nintendo's pride and the straw that broke Sega's back. It represents the pinnacle of Sqauresoft's history and in the eyes of many, no single player RPG has come close since. It also spawned one of the most recognisable bad guys in gaming history. The heavy anime style gives it a very Japanese feel, Nobuo's music is fantastic, from the energetic guitar based battle themes to the heartwrenchingly sorrowful Aerith's theme. A game that excited a generation, filling our heads with unforgettable memories of an awesome, immersive experience. It's a must play for any hardcore RPG fanatic.

content:
21, 2014
												Ok, I was really doubting this game. I thought it wasn't going to be as all the fanboys says it would be. "OH MAH GAWD THIS IS BEST GAME EBER" basically that. So I played alittle and I'm like, it's alright. But let's say a year later, a really good youtube channel (The Completionists') were doing a special on FF7. Since I saw that, I'm like, "Hey! Why not finish this game so I don't get any spoilers from the video!" It jurastically changed from that. I couldn't stop playing. It's like it was sucking me into this game. Although if it weren't for the PS1 music patch for this game, I wouldn't be here and playing this version, because I would be playing on the PS1 (but if I would have, it would take years because I never get on my PS1 on a daily basis). The graphics are a step up, and if you see a side-by-side comparison of the original vs this one, you only see that the character models are more high-def, and the pre-rendered graphics are displayed in a better resolution. Other than that, there is no difference gameplay-wise, except for the SUPER-OP character booster. What it does is that it makes any 3 of your characters in your party right now have 9999 hp and 999 mp (I'm not sure on the gil, it wasn't 99,999 but it was like 60,000 or something like that) other than that, it doesn't give you status buffs, nothing else. Just that (preety weird if you ask me, but you know, Square Enix will make anything worse *Puts on sunglasses*). It will also feel weird the first times using the keyboard, and I have found some mini-games unplayable when using my layout (A is OK, B is CANCEL, D is MENU, Space for START, Shift for SWITCH, Page Up and Down for left and right bumpers 'PS1 controller') and it is real nice that you can use an XBOX 360 controller even though I don't have one, I just use my PS3 controller and have some software to emulate the 360 (I'm not going in-depth about that). You can also use a PS2 controller, but you need an adapter (the best way to play if you ask me, but again, I don't have an adapter). In conclusion, it is the best Final Fantasy I've ever played, but not the best game I ever played.

content:
er 28, 2013
												There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

Go grab yourself a physical copy and an emulator, it'll be better in the long run.

er 28, 2013
												There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 8, 2013
												Underneath the crusty PC port is the game I love, shining like a jewel. But, with cloudsaving that, more often that not, doesn't work, an immensely rocky entry because of an account requirement for a single-player  game that should not have been a concern even months after launch on Steam, and multiple progress stealing crashes, FF7 for PC is not a game I can recommend, even as a diehard fan. It is just too much hassle, both in and out of the game.Update: Not really as upset with the game, but I still don't recommend the game, even to my friends. People who love Final Fantasy will play this regardless, just as I have. I don't encounter nearly as many crashes as I used to because I play it on a stronger computer, but have still encountered some. Cloudsaving is still a consistent problem, however. Though it works more than it doesn't, the times it doesn't are frustrating and can go on for as long as an entire day. The irony in this is that the player requires an account or linking of Facebook info, in part, because of this feature. To force a player to go to such lengths just to play a game that never required this in the first place for a feature that works so infrequently is not a good justification. This is not even mentioning that Steam has these functions covered, should the effort be put in. In text, it seems like a poor port.

content:
8, 2014
												Classic game, reproduced faithfully to the original, for better or worse.  A remastered soundtrack would have been excellent, hopefully and easy-to-implement mod will come around in the near future.Caveat Emptor, if you already have this game through Squaresoft- your achievements there will carry over, but there is no way to merge save files.  FYI for completionists, start a fresh game through steam.Recommended for nostalgia and long stretches of inactivity.  Expect 60ish hours for a first playthrough, 40 the second and so on.  Figuring out the ultimate weapons on your own is much more rewarding than using a walkthrough.  However, in the interest of not missing something you only get one chance of acquiring (happens VERY often in this game), check out the "Caves of Narshe" website for their guide on "Missable items."

y 4, 2014
												I don't know where to start, but FFVII is one of my fav game for years now. When I first met with the title Final Fantasy, it was on my PSX many years ago. Right now the visuals are outdated. Ofcourse they are, because the game is 16-17 years old (almost an adult). But still one of the best jrpg out there in my opinion. You could ask me, that why is it so good, I will tell it, but remember, these are only MY opinions, not facts. First, i loved the whole story, the flashbacks, backgrounds of the characters. Second, i rly loved almost every music in the game (Imo Cosmo Canyon Theme is the best). And the third, that i like the most and miss in many other games, these are the mini games. For me the most fun was the Chocobo racing and the Chocobo farm. And one more thing, if I'm correct, then FFVII was the Game of the year in 1997. And one little thing, if anyone saw the movie Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children, but never tried the game, then I highly recommend atleast 1 playthrough.Update:Oh boy and I'm still waiting for the FF7 Remake. Sadly it will be a PS4 exclusive title, but for me still a must have and the only reason to buy a PS4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII has long been one of my all-time favorite games.  The updated Steam version corrects some of the problems that occured on modern Windows systems due to some rushed coding on the original PC version, but more importantly, it makes a formerly rare PC game available once again.  The plot of FF7 is very rich and detailed, but unfortunately poor translation and the rush to complete the game caused the story to be very confusing.  In many ways, the mystery of the plot adds to the game experience, while it does cause some frustration at the end.  Because of the rich storyline, I found it was worth many playthroughs over the years to look for the additional clues and hidden plot points that explain some of the details and where all the characters fit in.And it's the characters that make the game interesting.  The primary cast of Cloud, Tifa, Barrett, Aeris, and Sephiroth remain some of gaming's most iconic and memorable characters.  And the supporting characters, major and minor, are also fascinating.  The guilt and dual-nature of Vincent Valentine, the relationship between Cid and Shera and his regret, Reeve's internal conflict, the stories of characters like Zack, Ifalna, and Lucrecia who reveal the origins of the crisis, are all interesting to explore and witness, along with the villians such as Rufus, Don Corneo, and of course, the truly despicable Hojo.  This is a story where people aren't always who you think they are, characters are in conflict with each other and themselves, and terrible losses occur on the way.  For gamers of my generation, there is a single scene I won't divulge here, but you'll know it when you see it, that sticks with you long after the game because of how strong the characters are.  As far as the game mechanics, it's pretty well done.  FF7 introduced the ATB timing system to Final Fantasy games, which combined real-time and turn-based mechanics very well.  Like other FF games, it's about a lot of stats, a lot of random fighting for experience and AP, and I lot of organizing equipment screens, but the systems in FF7 are not so intimidating or confusing as other games in the genre.  Many of the stats don't have a lot of importance in most situations, making fine-tuning the numbers less necessary so long as the characters are leveling enough and have decent gear.  What makes FF7 unique, even among FF games, is the materia system.  By arranging gems called materia, a character can gain magic and special abilities and change them as necessary between fights.  Unlike FF8's junction system which discouraged the use of magic, FF7's materia grows in strength when it is used and equipped.  The materia system is something I've always liked about the game.In many ways, the game hasn't aged perfectly.  Mainly the graphics, and the wonderful soundtrack was originally presented in a midi format. This version updates the midi to OGG, but still isn't great.  Unfortunately, the excellent work by the Qhimm forums on restoring the PC version of this game to greatness is not compatible with the new release of the game, only the original and Platinum Hits versions.  Overall, this game is legendary, and essential for anyone who calls themselves a gamer.  If you play normally, expect 40 hours of gameplay, if you choose to explore and look at everything while combing for secrets, make that 60-80, and if you rush and use walkthroughs, you can do it in 20.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 7, 2015
												Well well, what must I say about this game, voted as one of the greatest video games of all time, seen as one of the best games in the Final Fantasy franchise, and known for its colossal impact on gaming? Well. If your a gamer like me, who plays games by heart and not eyes (heart being story and eyes being blown away from games featuring explosions guns and violence), then this is a game for YOU. Before I go in depth of how amazing this game is, I must tell you how I got into the Final Fantasy franchise. As a kid I shied away from the series because honestly the roman numerals in the games was just too confusing and at the time I was a strict Nintendo fanboy. Times have changed, I am no longer a strict Nintendo fanboy though I still am but now I accept other games. I gave Final Fantasy 1 a try and quickly got hooked. Then I moved on to 2 and at that point it was clear I am now a Final Fantasy fanboy. I then went to 3, and at the time (all of this happened recently btw), there was a Steam deal going on. The Square Enix publisher discount stuff. Final Fantasy 7 and 8 were in that, and I had some spare change and decided it would be a fantastic idea to purchase two Final Fantasy games with the highest amount of reputation within the franchise. I did not regret that decision, it was clearly worth buying. Now, back to our discussion on why the game is great. This game, is addictive. No, not addictive in a bad way like Minecraft (You know, playing all day losing your mind). Addictive story-wise. The story in this game is ENGAGING ON SOO MANY LEVELS. IT DOES NOT AT ALL FEEL LIKE I AM PLAYING A GAME ITSELF, BUT WATCHING A MOVIE WITH A DEEP STORY AND AMAZING CUTSCENES AND FLASHBACKS. The gameplay itself is interesting and apealing to me. When I play the game, I don't care for the gameplay, I am anxious to see what happens next in the story. When a game gets you feeling like this, it is clear why Final Fantasy 7 is regarded or arguably one of the greatest games of all time. Its games like this one we just don't see anymore, it really does suck because I myself wish that these games with all these DLC's and micro-transactions would just STOP and use this game as an analogy to what a perfect game should be. This game is a classic, I had no problems with it other than how frustrating it was to get my freakin Square Enix account setup. If you can get past that one problem, you got yourself a perfect beautiful game right here. In conclusion, I say if you are one who enjoys a great story with fun gameplay, then this game is worth your 12 dollars. Or, at the moment if the deal is still going, its half off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII has long been one of my all-time favorite games.  The updated Steam version corrects some of the problems that occured on modern Windows systems due to some rushed coding on the original PC version, but more importantly, it makes a formerly rare PC game available once again.  The plot of FF7 is very rich and detailed, but unfortunately poor translation and the rush to complete the game caused the story to be very confusing.  In many ways, the mystery of the plot adds to the game experience, while it does cause some frustration at the end.  Because of the rich storyline, I found it was worth many playthroughs over the years to look for the additional clues and hidden plot points that explain some of the details and where all the characters fit in.And it's the characters that make the game interesting.  The primary cast of Cloud, Tifa, Barrett, Aeris, and Sephiroth remain some of gaming's most iconic and memorable characters.  And the supporting characters, major and minor, are also fascinating.  The guilt and dual-nature of Vincent Valentine, the relationship between Cid and Shera and his regret, Reeve's internal conflict, the stories of characters like Zack, Ifalna, and Lucrecia who reveal the origins of the crisis, are all interesting to explore and witness, along with the villians such as Rufus, Don Corneo, and of course, the truly despicable Hojo.  This is a story where people aren't always who you think they are, characters are in conflict with each other and themselves, and terrible losses occur on the way.  For gamers of my generation, there is a single scene I won't divulge here, but you'll know it when you see it, that sticks with you long after the game because of how strong the characters are.  As far as the game mechanics, it's pretty well done.  FF7 introduced the ATB timing system to Final Fantasy games, which combined real-time and turn-based mechanics very well.  Like other FF games, it's about a lot of stats, a lot of random fighting for experience and AP, and I lot of organizing equipment screens, but the systems in FF7 are not so intimidating or confusing as other games in the genre.  Many of the stats don't have a lot of importance in most situations, making fine-tuning the numbers less necessary so long as the characters are leveling enough and have decent gear.  What makes FF7 unique, even among FF games, is the materia system.  By arranging gems called materia, a character can gain magic and special abilities and change them as necessary between fights.  Unlike FF8's junction system which discouraged the use of magic, FF7's materia grows in strength when it is used and equipped.  The materia system is something I've always liked about the game.In many ways, the game hasn't aged perfectly.  Mainly the graphics, and the wonderful soundtrack was originally presented in a midi format. This version updates the midi to OGG, but still isn't great.  Unfortunately, the excellent work by the Qhimm forums on restoring the PC version of this game to greatness is not compatible with the new release of the game, only the original and Platinum Hits versions.  Overall, this game is legendary, and essential for anyone who calls themselves a gamer.  If you play normally, expect 40 hours of gameplay, if you choose to explore and look at everything while combing for secrets, make that 60-80, and if you rush and use walkthroughs, you can do it in 20.

content:
ry 7, 2015
												There are no words for how disappointed I am with this version of FF7. Required log ins, midi music tracks instead of the playstation ones, grainy super low-res video, stretched rather then up-scaled textures and world maps, and last but not least a confusing control scheme. This isn't a 2013 rerelease, its the exact same pc port from 1998 with the only differances being achievements and that you have to log in now.  Other then that Square-Enix didn't even put in the most trival effort to improve the game. Thankfully there are modders out there doing what Square-Enix is too lazy to and much more. If you don't mind losing the trainer and achievements I'd look into the various graphic and gameplay enchancement mods availible on the net to make the game at very least more playable.Edit: The midi music was due to a bad download. After deleting the local files and reinstalling I found I had PSX music. Still not going to recommend this game though, as the only way I found it playable is with the Tifas Bootleg mod compolation.

content:
, 2013
												Even after 16 years since it's original release, Final Fantasy VII is, without a doubt, one of the absolute best RPGs in existence. It's characters, story, and gameplay are some of the finest the JRPG market has ever had. This is a game that anyone should play through at least once. This port of the classic is definently worth purchasing for both veterans of FFVII and first-timers alike. Cloud saving is a very nifty feature that allows you to play your saves on multiple computers, although there are occasionaly network issues with it. The character booster will be a great tool for those who want to observe the story rather than focus on hours of grinding. The textures have been polished up nicely, and the FMVs look a lot smoother than before. Overall, this is a gaming experience worth having, and this is the perfect version for those who wish to try it for the first time. My only recommendation: Make sure you have a controller, as the standard keyboard controls are a bit wonky.

												I was seriously loving this game, up until the point where all of my saved game files were missing except for one I had towards the beginning of the game. My time played is a stretch, since I left the game on for some time, but I still had put in a decent amount of time goofing around, stealing ethers, learning monster skills, etc. So, now I've lost that progress, and I can either restart or quit. I've read up that this has something to do with cloud saving, but this game has been on steam long enough that it should have been fixed a LONG time ago. In my mind, this is the equivalent of if square had come into my childhood home, taken my ps1 memory card, doused it in gasoline and then flipped me the bird as they dropped the match. I'm sure I'll at some point grind my way back to where I was and use the work around, but if you don't want the headache, find another way to play this game. +Great story+Great old school RPG elements+Awesome characters-Takes all of those things and deletes them on a whim

content:
y 17, 2015
												Final Fantasy VII is about a stuggling jack of all trades who, at one point, questions his sexual outlook. After spending some time living as a lady in the slums, he realises he isn't meant for such roots and decides to wage war on the local pimp who ♥♥♥♥♥s out woman as if they were objects.Together, with the help of his female companions, they strike down the slumdog pimp and soon set their sites on bigger motions in works, Why stop the lesser evils when they can overthrow a government who oppress their people in order to gain monopoly for themselves?Our hero, Cloud, then sets off, hesitantly, on his way to see change brought to the land and its people. Through trying times, he bonds well with those around him and gains invaluable strength and bravey through out. Soon the group learn they are in way over their heads when they come across a talking dog, who's tail is constantly on fire (he doesn't seem to mind, though), and through the actions of said dog, they learn of a great evil at work. Sephiroth.Sephiroth was once a mentor, an idol and symbol of hope to Cloud, and the world at large. However, after learning of dark secrets kept from him, Sephiroth seeks vegence on those who wronged him - the Goverment known as Shinra. He learns he is nothing more than a lab experiment and that his mother was an alien. Naturally, Sephiroth is all like "hold the damn phone here, guys... The hell is this?" - having never met his mother, his desire to be passionately held becomes unbearable, to the point of dangerous obsession. He even steals her dead head.So, Cloud and his merry crew, who at this point are like "... This guy is mental, he's trying to summon a meteor with magic to kill everyone on the planet because he has mother issues... We should really do something about that", go about in search of an even greater evil. That being Septhiroth.After some forsakend, unforgiveable, and downright ♥♥♥♥ing twisted, ♥♥♥♥ sucking, lego ♥♥♥♥ing, herpes ridden deaths and Cloud loosing his mind, because, you know... He isn't actually the person he thinks he is, they confront Septhiroth, give him a slap on the rest and tell him "Mummy said you should be a good boy now".That's pretty much Final Fantasy VII, oh and there's also naked men bouncing around on beds, girls dressed as beads... I mean BEES, some weird ninja girl obsessed with stealing and a dude with a gun for and arm who suffers with suicidal tendancy. Oh and there is Zack Fair. And snow boarding, there's also a dating simulation thing in there. Did I mention future seeing stuffed animals with cats on their heads who are controlled by some dude in a goverment building?9/10.

It is far easier and more convenient for me to download this game illegally - that is a sad, sad fact.Square Enix, please discontinue your bad service and embrace Steam.

content:
2014
												As someone who just missed this game when it came out, I was worried that I wouldn't be able to enjoy it so many years later, especially with so much hype around it.  Much to my great excitement, it not only held up, but far exceeded my expectations!  The story was great, with so many more twists than the lone one everyone knows, and the characters really stand out as some of the most colorful I've experienced.  If you're like me and have always meant to play this game but just haven't had a chance, snag yourself a copy and enjoy!(A note: The cloud saving is off by default and very finicky.  If you only intend to play on one computer, this won't be a problem, as it will just save locally.  If you plan on playing across a couple computers, you should go into the settings from the launch screen and enable cloud saving before you start to save yourself some trouble.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 7, 2015
												Well well, what must I say about this game, voted as one of the greatest video games of all time, seen as one of the best games in the Final Fantasy franchise, and known for its colossal impact on gaming? Well. If your a gamer like me, who plays games by heart and not eyes (heart being story and eyes being blown away from games featuring explosions guns and violence), then this is a game for YOU. Before I go in depth of how amazing this game is, I must tell you how I got into the Final Fantasy franchise. As a kid I shied away from the series because honestly the roman numerals in the games was just too confusing and at the time I was a strict Nintendo fanboy. Times have changed, I am no longer a strict Nintendo fanboy though I still am but now I accept other games. I gave Final Fantasy 1 a try and quickly got hooked. Then I moved on to 2 and at that point it was clear I am now a Final Fantasy fanboy. I then went to 3, and at the time (all of this happened recently btw), there was a Steam deal going on. The Square Enix publisher discount stuff. Final Fantasy 7 and 8 were in that, and I had some spare change and decided it would be a fantastic idea to purchase two Final Fantasy games with the highest amount of reputation within the franchise. I did not regret that decision, it was clearly worth buying. Now, back to our discussion on why the game is great. This game, is addictive. No, not addictive in a bad way like Minecraft (You know, playing all day losing your mind). Addictive story-wise. The story in this game is ENGAGING ON SOO MANY LEVELS. IT DOES NOT AT ALL FEEL LIKE I AM PLAYING A GAME ITSELF, BUT WATCHING A MOVIE WITH A DEEP STORY AND AMAZING CUTSCENES AND FLASHBACKS. The gameplay itself is interesting and apealing to me. When I play the game, I don't care for the gameplay, I am anxious to see what happens next in the story. When a game gets you feeling like this, it is clear why Final Fantasy 7 is regarded or arguably one of the greatest games of all time. Its games like this one we just don't see anymore, it really does suck because I myself wish that these games with all these DLC's and micro-transactions would just STOP and use this game as an analogy to what a perfect game should be. This game is a classic, I had no problems with it other than how frustrating it was to get my freakin Square Enix account setup. If you can get past that one problem, you got yourself a perfect beautiful game right here. In conclusion, I say if you are one who enjoys a great story with fun gameplay, then this game is worth your 12 dollars. Or, at the moment if the deal is still going, its half off.

content:
ber 12, 2014
												I absolutely loved this game on the PS1 and when this was released on steam my wallet jumped out of my pants from the other room and started to fill out my payment information! I was petrified to see this very odd encounter that was unfolding before my very eyes. Once the payment was complete and of course printing out my confirmation email and carefully writing down my confirmation number for my personal records I quickly installed and attempted to play my newly but oddly obtained copy of Final Fantasy 7!  I checked all the options within the launcher to make sure the upmost  compatibility. I click play and my screen goes black...appears this very ominous logo on my screen "SQUARESOFT". I wait.....I wait some more....I click, I press ESC, my heart begins to race as this mysterious logo just stays on my screen! I rapidly start spamming all the keys on my keyboard! nothing happens! I finally Ctrl+alt+tab and I become blinded by this blueish-green screen with a few options. I choose "Open Task Manager" and a new window appears! I decide to put this horrible experience to an end, I had to make this my seventh and final attempt to live this fantasy.

content:
er 17, 2013
												This was my very first Final Fantasy game and still one of my favorites in the series and of my greatest childhood memories, i loved this game back then and i still do today, but i will say that it is not the best Final Fantasy game and it is by far the most overrated one in the franchise.The materia system without a doubt my favorite thing about this game and is my favorite "leveling" system of all the Final Fantasy Games.The music is great just like most of Nobuo Uematsu's work, one of my favorite things about this game.The steam version also includes the PS1 soundtrack the original PC version didn't have :D (From what i'v heard it wasn't included at first when the game launched on steam until a few months later which is a lazy move on Square's part)! One of Nobuo's best works alongside Final Fantasy VIII.The story is not the game's strongest part but its far from bad.Most of the characters are pretty good though but not best in the series.The graphics may look silly by todays standards but back when it first came out i found them really impressive.However the minigames in this game are definently the worst part of this game, the chocobo racing is decent, raising them however is time consuming but still kinda fun, the Bike Race is fun too but aside from that none of the other minigames are fun or intresting.Also this might be somewhat of a nitpick but i think the Steam achievements are just made up with no effort at all, boring as ♥♥♥♥ and not intresting at all, oh wellFinal Verdict 8.8/10 if you are a Final Fantasy fan and you haven't played it yet i'd say its worth your time, and for those who havent gotten into the series its a decent game to start with.

content:
er 2, 2013
												It's my first Final Fantasy game and up to now very cool! :-)If u wanna play this game without problems with the cloud saving, u have to exit FF7. Now open the Windows Explorer with the path to ur documents (e.g. C:\Users\<USER>\Documents\Square Enix\FINAL FANTASY VII Steam). Here u have to rename the file networkSettings.dat and start FF7 again. With this change the game work without cloud saving, which means u have to handle the backups of ur savegame by urself.

												If you're looking at the reviews for this you're either A.) Never played this game and looking to see what it is about...or B.) Played it and are looking to see how Steam does it.If you're an "A" -- don't worry this game has an amazing story, and in my humble opinion, is one of the greatest RPG's ever made.  Go ahead and spend the MASSIVE $11 (I paid $40 for it retail the day it came out for the good ole PlayStation!)  The review for you "B" guys is below.Despite some personal technical difficulties with saves and re-downloading this is for the most part much improved over the original version.  I'm not 100% on this but I feel like the dialogue got cleaned up a lot, it just flows more like native English and less like a half-decent Japanese translation to English.  The only downside to me is that it doesn't seem to use the PS style of controller I wanted to use for playing it -- at least it doesn't let me use it very well.  However, it is perfectly fine for the mouse and keyboard.

content:
1, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is universally recognized as the best installment of the series, and maybe one of the best RPG ever. I played the original, on the PS1, all the way through at least four or five times. FF7 was the only game I liked enough to get me to shell out the extra 20 bucks for the guide, just so I could find and/or beat every little side quest or hidden area. It absorbed many countless hours of my youth.Not to long ago, I found FF7 on Steam and quickly bought it for second time. Now I never did find my old guide (not that you need it with the internet), but I played Final Fantasy VII once again and loved every minute of it. I was reminded of it’s great story and characters, awesome weapons with unique leveling up, the way powers can be mixed together, and the great interface for both battle and world map. I enjoy that you can spend hours racing giant birds around for an awesome hidden item or fighting through a tough dungeon for a unique weapon. But the game doesn’t make you, very little of the required gameplay is grinding. This game does not require continuous, fast button mashing. So if you like to take frequent, short breaks from the game controller to enhance your video gaming experience, Final Fantasy VII is great for that.After completing this game once again, even though it took a bit longer because of that pesky thing known as a job, I still find it to be my favorite game ever. It has everything that made it great on the PS1, but the PC version is much smoother because of the updated hardware. If are a fan of the original, have played others in the series, or just enjoy RPGs or good games, it will be more than worth it to buy FF7, a great game all around.

content:
er 28, 2013
												FF7 is a monolith of my childhood. How do you review a game with so much hype and pomp and fanatical emotion? It's easier than I thought it would be, given that I can play it again. It's just like I remember. FF7 is like putting on a warm sweater and drinking hot cider. It's a comfort-game. Let me explain.FF7 came out when I was 11. I did not get to play it until I was 12. Everyone told me how great it was--and how it was introducing western audiences to the Japanese RPG world by storm. So when I got a used Playstation, I got the game.I did not know it at the time, but this FF game was unlike the six that preceeded it in terms of setting and magic system. So I had no bias to base my analysis off of. All I knew was that the Materia system was great. It was easy to use and learn--and as I got better at the game, I began to think up more complex combinations of Materia and equipment. (Woo, Curse Ring and then Added Effect/Destruct in linked Armor slots) There were literally, thousands of combinations. And that's not even touching Enemy-Skill, Morph and Manipulate.The Materia system was rock solid. You could completely customize what characters you felt would be best for certain combinations. You weren't constrained by this idea of a Character Class--at least in regards to magic. In terms of weapons, yes, perhaps that was more restricted--but I loved it. Everyone was different--it was perfect. You could create an awesome balance between tanks like Barret and speedsters like Tifa---with characters like Nanaki, Vincent and Yuffie--who were skilled physically and magically.And of course, you can't have a game without good characters. Despite the foamy mustache that Square has gotten from milking FF7 for everything its got--don't believe what they've done to Cloud. In FF7, he was not the whiny little angst-machine that Square has turned him into. He went through big things in FF7 and he got low--but he came back. He got back up, dusted himself off and kept going. That was the entire point. But Square would have you thinking he spends all his time whining and moping around. Not true. When Advent Children came out, I was quite confused because their Cloud wasn't acting like...well, Cloud. Aeris is your Mary Sue Last of her Race, Magic MacGuffin Carrier Female White Mage thing. I make a point to get her out of my party ASAP. This is only because I personally don't like her. I hate her snippy attitude, her selfishness and her blatant disregard of everyone around her--except for Cloud. She is the most irritating character. However---that is just my personal opinion (besides, the game did me a solid and I forgave them at, you know, That Part). As a character--Aeris moves the plot along and she IS a helluva powerful White Mage/Magic User. When I have to have her with me, I always put Cover on her and Fury---so whenever she takes a hit for someone, it ramps up her Limit Break bar and then she busts out the Holy magic.Tifa kind of lists back and forth between annoying and cool. She's the fistfighter/monk character and between her and Aeris, I'll take Tifa. She can deal some real damage (Powersoul + Curse Ring = Constant 4x damage infliction) and she has a real connection with Cloud. Whereas with Aeris--her thing with Cloud feels very shallow---Tifa actually feels very natural with Cloud. She cares about him, deeply. And when you learn about him--he cares about her.Barret is your angry tank/heavy gunner. I would say he's probably the least characterized (except for Cait Sith) but he's a good long range strong arm. Nanaki, I really like too---he's very calm, collected and thoughtful. He's very reasonable, not one o pin blame like Barrett does sometimes.Cid Highwind is my favorite--tough-talking roughneck chainsmoking pilot. He gets jipped a lot for some reason. But he's the Reluctant Leader. He can lead, he's fine with leading---but he can also follow. He's not insecure like Barrett and if he needs to step up, he does. And his crew respects him for it. He's got balls--but he's not a jerk. Cid curses and is kind of rough and tumble---but when he makes that one short speech about how their planet is wandering small and lonely in the universe, it shows a little more in there.Yuffie is my favorite of the ladies. Okay, yes, she'll steal your stuff---but she has so much personality (and she doesn't fawn over Cloud). She's straight-forward, to the point, hilariously awful sometimes. And once you get her leveled up--she is a straight up badass. One of my favorite things to do when Cid is the leader---is put her, Vincent and Cid together to go on the Train Mission. OMG, funny. She is so hilarious. She's like a Chaotic Neutral---might save your life, might steal your car. And I love that about her. They seem to have gotten away from her character type later--which I think is a real shame. (Also, I ship Yuffie and Reno forever.)And then, of course, the Big Bad. THE Big Bad. Sephiroth. A psychotic momma's boy, who will kil you, your dog, your dog's puppies, your kitchen table and then burn your house down. He literally does not give a crap about anyone or anything--but gaining power and reclaiming Gaia for Jenova. His brutality is brought home--and made personal. Cloud's backstory with Tifa in Nibelheim, Zack and then finally culminating with Aeris in the Forgotten City. His menace, his power--its legendary. You hear about Sephiroth at the very beginning of the game. You don't even see him until several hours later into gameplay. And even then--its in Cloud's flashback. The way Sephiroth is presented is masterful. They talked it up, told you how strong and crazy-evil he was, built and built and built on it--until you finally get to see him for yourself and for once, he's everything that you've heard.This was what made it for me. Excellent pacing, a good blend of character types so that you can customize your party how you wanted (I'd rather not like a character, than be indifferent to the characters; FF8's characters were so bland--I hated it), an intuitive and creative magic and battle system, tons of sidequests, hours and hours of things to do. To just explore the World Map.I feel like this was Square at its very best. When they wrote a complex but compelling story, a game where--each time I play, I find something I didn't know was there. I only recently discovered the Curse Ring in Mideel--or if you visit Johnny's parents in Sector 7 before its destroyed, his father talks about Nibelheim (I was like: WHOA!) and countless other small details that enrich the gameplay. Its what keeps me coming back over and over again. I've played this game countless times--and each time, I enjoy it.   Yeah, the graphics are old. It doesn't matter--its the story, the mechanics, the characters. Advent Children had beautiful graphics, beautiful. But its story was completely lame, the plot was ridiculously stupid--it was all just fanservice. So I dont even bother with all the other stuff that Square came out with to milk the FF7 cow. I'd say they should just remake FF7---but I'm afraid they'd start messing around and changing things. Don't trust 'em. Haha.This is one game--where it lived up to its hype. It exceeded my expectations. I saw FF7 when it came out on EA's website and I about had a heart attack. I bought instantly, that very night, that minute. And then about a week later, it came out on Steam. And I got another copy on Steam--just so that I'd always have it. Look passed the graphics, immerse yourself in the story and the dynamic characters. It's worth it. I would have paid $30 for a copy of this game--and they're selling it for $12. Worth every penny.

content:
, 2015
-Quick Review-Final Fantasy VII (FF7) is a turn-based RPG that was released in 1997 on the Play Station Console by Square Co., Ltd (in 2003 they merged with Enix, creating "Square Enix"). Final Fantasy VII (FFV) is one of the most popular games in the series.-please note before purchase-I need to add a comment that, I tend to review the game alone, however for Final Fantasy VII you are required to creature (or use an existing) Square Enix account. Achievements/Steam-Achievements, and other features are accessible through that account... I don't really know many of the perks because I just jumped through the hoops to play the game. But to some people, that's a deal breaker.I just wanted to give people a heads up. Thank you for reading the rest of the review.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You play the game as the main protagonist "Cloud", whom is probably tied for being the most iconic figure in the series with the antagonist "Sephiroth". You start the game as a member of the terrorist group AVALANCHE, Cloud has just been hired and is providing combat assistance to the group... Good thing too, the raid doesn't go nearly as planned.As the story progresses you're limited to only to the city of "Midgar", after hitting the pinnacle of the story within Midgar (oh, you'll know what I'm talking about, if you make it that far. I was praying for a save point, I wanted to go to bed). You'll suddenly discover the world is a much larger place then you ever thought.To people who are new to the series, it's easy to brush it off as "oh, that's nice, a large world map *yawn*." Try to imagine seeing it as a little kid playing the PlayStation? To many of my friends this was the first game in the genre they had played, so naturally it's actually a very memorable experience. After this excellent transition, you realize "wow, this game is going to be a big long one" and it is, it came in 3 disk set.Game Play: I needed to do some research to refresh some of the terms used to describe the Final Fantasy VII combat system. I have played several Turn-based RPG's, however FF7 utilizes "Active Time Battle". The main difference is that there's a visible timer that counts down before you can make your next move.I had no idea that's how the game worked, so when I first played and my enemy had hit me three times while I was trying to learn the menu... well... needless to say I was more than a little surprised. "WHAT! You cheaters! I don't know what any of these moves do!" I have no shame in admitting I almost lost my first battle, and I lost my first boss battle in the first 20 minutes of the game. Yeah, go ahead and laugh at me; but this was my first time encountering that mechanic.Outside of the combat, there are many in-game events that you do throughout FF7, sometimes it's pressing key sequences to ride a snowboard, or chocobo, or arm wrestle. While very fun with a controller and on the original game console... with a keyboard and mouse the controls and tutorial still use the old button names. So there's extra difficulty trying to accomplish those. I end up failing MOST mini events because I don't know which button I'm pressing."Press select" mmmmk, letssseee... which one is select... *presses X* *Cloud face plants*. Well that was fun, let's try that again...Achievements: There are 36 Achievements for Final Fantasy VII, and four categories; 1) Person joins your party, 2) you do your first breaker limit with that character, 3) you do your last breaker limit with that character, 4) Some ridicules long end game achievement.I've played 26 hours so far (05/14/15) and only have 10/36 achievements, so naturally getting all the steam achievements will be quite an accomplishment in this game.Price: Final Fantasy VII is priced at $11.99, considering the amount of time you'll spend playing FF7 to get through the whole story alone, that's a very fair price. However, if you're just collecting games to your "maybe I'll play it someday" list, you should probably wait for a steam sale.Conclusion: The only real negative things I have to say about the game is that I don't like making accounts to log into an offline-game (but that's just the way it is), and using a keyboard isn't nearly as streamlined and seamless as using a controller.I personally love the story, the characters, and will be spending more time playing the game, I suspect I've just moved on to disk 2, So I've still got a lot farther to go before I beat the game... Then there's the whole thing about figuring out the achievements.I recommend this game to anyone who played the original game and wishes for some nostalgia, people who want to experience "Active Time Battle" game play in an RPG, or anyone casually interested in the story behind any of the characters in the FF7 world.

content:
er 17, 2013
												This was my very first Final Fantasy game and still one of my favorites in the series and of my greatest childhood memories, i loved this game back then and i still do today, but i will say that it is not the best Final Fantasy game and it is by far the most overrated one in the franchise.The materia system without a doubt my favorite thing about this game and is my favorite "leveling" system of all the Final Fantasy Games.The music is great just like most of Nobuo Uematsu's work, one of my favorite things about this game.The steam version also includes the PS1 soundtrack the original PC version didn't have :D (From what i'v heard it wasn't included at first when the game launched on steam until a few months later which is a lazy move on Square's part)! One of Nobuo's best works alongside Final Fantasy VIII.The story is not the game's strongest part but its far from bad.Most of the characters are pretty good though but not best in the series.The graphics may look silly by todays standards but back when it first came out i found them really impressive.However the minigames in this game are definently the worst part of this game, the chocobo racing is decent, raising them however is time consuming but still kinda fun, the Bike Race is fun too but aside from that none of the other minigames are fun or intresting.Also this might be somewhat of a nitpick but i think the Steam achievements are just made up with no effort at all, boring as ♥♥♥♥ and not intresting at all, oh wellFinal Verdict 8.8/10 if you are a Final Fantasy fan and you haven't played it yet i'd say its worth your time, and for those who havent gotten into the series its a decent game to start with.

content:
r 5, 2013
												There's really not much I can say about Final Fantasy 7 that hasn't already been said. It was a revolutionary game and it changed the face of RPGs forever. Some say it was for the best, others disagree.In any case you've likely heard all the JRPG stereotypes, the random battles, and the menu based combat. The storyline is extremely character driven, and it's one of the highlights of the entire experience. That's not counting the large world you explore, the sidequests and all the optional content. Much of which most players don't know about until they read a wiki. Final Fantasy 7 is a game about replayability and choices, and one that anyone can enjoy.
